content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												"Hey, I just finished E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy!" Did I?Everyone who did a playthrough will know what I'm talking about. So, my second time is still to come but I completed one complete possible storyline or how you might call it.So what is this game like? [Note: You can still read my very first impression at the very bottom.]One word that describes it - many might agree: "Strange." Well, that doesn't say much though it really is the case with this game. It has an overwhelming feel to it - this is the case for the writing, the style and the gameplay. Though you don't necessarily have to sink into this universe and can just scrap the surface (gameplaywise and storywise) I recommend to take your time with this game. It pays off. Much has been said so I will just list some things I find worth mentioning to give you an impression:- Art/Style: Set in a Sci-Fi-dystopian world with an asian touch - it feels like a...well...futuristic, steampunk chinatown universe at times.- Music: What shall I say, this creates atmosphere at it's best.- Gameplay: Confusing right from the beginning as it's a blend of FPS with deep RPG-similar mechanics. Your possibilities range from Research, to classic leveling up to some sort of skill tree etc. At the very beginning you can pre-customize your character in the way intended. It may be decisive if you want to choose a certain approach like stealth, hacking, combat etc.The maps are huge and you get lost pretty easily - one might criticize that. Also the level design isn't the best at times. The campaign is loosely structured with somewhat missions - each has its specific main goals and possible side-goals you may want to achieve or not, you can progress though without caring. From time to time the interaction with the NPCs will let you or force you to make decisions that affect your playthrough experience.- Other feature worth mentioning: This game is "circular" in it's very best sense - multiple playthroughs intended, there is no real ending as there is no real end (storywise, gamewise). Replayability: 100%________________________________________________This is a very very first impression comment on the game and I just want to share one thing with you guys because it's something remarkable for me as a gamer:It was the first time after a long period of FPS-gaming time that holding a gun in my hands evoked some kind of feeling. It just felt fresh and astonishing and I can't explain why. Well, there is something more to it.There has been a lot of talk about shooters and immersion and experience.Immersion - there you go.(I will elaborate on this after I progress in the game. For now - there has already been talked about the cyber-steampunk setting with the asian touch a lot as well as the soundtrack and so on. Go have a read if you like.)

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Reviewing a game like E.Y.E comprehensively isn't an easy task, none the less lets have a stab at it.The game makes a thematic spin on a common premise:- You are a super soldier with Amnesia- There is a war going on- You are going to kill your way to victory in FPS gloryThis is where is leaves the standard model behind both in gameplay, aesthetic, theme and story.From a Gameplay perspective all skills and utilities are provided as a means of killing things. Even the medkit can be used to overdose someone.Hacking? use it to fry someone's brain or turn them crazy and make them attack their colleagues.Magic? Create a clone army of yourself and send them in to battle, or if you prefer the direct approach just teleport yourself "inside" your target enemy and make them explode.Stealth? Cloak up, jump over buildings, snipe people or slit their throats (or crush them with a hammer... or crush them by falling on them super-mario style)Guns? Guns.And on the topic of guns, this game really brings home the bacon with satisfying weaponry. Admittedly there are no super fancy guns that shoot lightning and razorblades and fire and particle effects and♥♥♥♥♥♥ but there are guns that will consume their entire magazine in a single trigger press because "Why only shoot one bullet when  you can shoot all the bullets?"There are handcannons that can destroy attack choppers, machine pistols that will decimate entire squads of terrorists and melee weapons that can be used to not only deflect bullets but cleave entire swaths of would be enemies in two.Even the entry level pistols are very satisfying to use as you put round after round into the ribcages and craniums of your aggressors.Theme? Dystopian cyberpunk inspired by somewhere between the matrix (it's shame that movie never had a sequel), bladerunner, johnny mnemonic and pretty much every major sci-fi movie from the 80's onwards, it's a real melting pot of♥♥♥♥♥♥and at times you will even notice design influences and likenesses to cult sci-fi shows like Farscape and videogames like shadowrun (the Genesis version, i never played the xbox/PC version).It is very atmospheric, and very well fitting. If you can ignore some of the now dated and chunky environments, but hey, the source engine can only be pushed so far.Now, story... Story is very difficult to explain in a simple review, but just be aware of the following: if you WANT a story, it is there, a full narrative of what's going on and who you are, but it is not going to hold  your hand. This isn't CoD where it's straightforward "good against evil", this isn't Deus Ex with it's over-arching evil corporations and terrorists (although there are plenty of both in E.Y.E), and this isn't <insert generic RPG> where the protagonist undergoes Tom Cruise syndrome (He's a good <x> but he has his doubts, UNTIL FEMALE <y> CAUSES HIM TO HAVE A CRISIS OF FAITH, AND IN ORDER TO WIN HER LOVE HE BECOMES A GREAT <x>. no really, that's every tom cruise movie ever.) before eventually facing off with the nemesis antagonist.tl;dr? wacky off-form shooter with RPG elements and a batshit crazy plot with cyberpunk aesthetics.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												E.Y.E....where to even begin?This game is an amalgamation of different genres. FPS, strategy, RPG, other ones that escape my mind at the moment. And it doesn't put them together well. It's unpolished as hell and it will most likely, no it WILL confuse you within the first 5 minutes of playtime.To me, that lack of polish and confusing game mechanics adds to its charm. Of course, for the first 10 hours, it really frustrated me. Starting your first game in E.Y.E is like sprinting full speed into a running saw blade. There's a huge learning curve. No one goes into this game an expert, but people who stay in the game long enough usually become one. It's not like most modern FPS games where you already know exactly what to do. Maybe there's like, 5 new things added in, but for the most part, it's the same formula. And it's like that because the developers already know that they can profit off of it.This game takes a completely different approach and it does it WELL. It gives no regard to what you, the player, are used to, or want in a game. No, this game exists because it WANTS to exist.There is no pandering to playerbases or boring, seen-it-all-before gameplay. Nuh-uh, this is something special.When you discover a game this..exotic, it makes you feel like you just found a gem. And while it most definitely isn't very refined, it doesn't honestly matter in the end if you keep with it. You come to appreciate its differences and love it for them.TL;DRjust buy the game already

content:
Posted: February 25
												Sooooooo..... let me tell it to ya straight...E.Y.E. is weird... It's really frickin' weird...You are futuristic space monk hacker badass, who's part of a rebellion against an Evil Federation(?) who rules the galaxy with an iron fist, all whilst kinda fighting/kinda not fighting amongst your allies, The Jian, who also hate you in return yet you guys both hate the federation, but are very willing to stab each other in the back on your merry way to freedom. Not to mention the space demons that show up at random times and ruin your day.And you also have a wife. Like seriously... WHAT!?All sillyness aside, E.Y.E.'s Plot is, while very good in some respects, very convoluted. There is soooome character development, but because of all of it's wackiness, I Didn't really feel very attached with most of the characters or even why I should care about them. Like, it literally takes THREE playthroughs before you finally figure out what's going on, not to mention the game doesn't explain itself very well. Especially when it comes to actually 𝑝𝑙𝑎𝑦𝑖𝑛𝑔 the game."Why Ciro, what do you mean by that? Doesn't the game give you a tutorial at the beginning of the game, like everygame should?" I hear you casual gamers out there say. And yes, it does and it does it decently. But only when it comes to the basics of the game. That's it. Okay, I kinda lied. It dooooes tell you how to hack and use some of your powers, but where this game really shines is it's damn near endless possibilities of approaching combat, (Which I'll get into later), And it doesn't tell you squat on how to use that or even understand it. And when you have a specific playstyle you want to use, but can't figure it out....Welp... Let's just say the game doesn't care and you have to result in being RunGunShootMan. And grinding.....Uuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuugh......Now I normally enjoy grinding, I find it very therapeutic at times. But Grinding in E.Y.E. can be a pain in the groin at times, especially since everything costs money and though getting money is easy,( Just kill everything!^^), Everything is expensive. And when I have to pay a lot of money to get further in my game.... Welp.... It's just not fun. Like space demons. Lemme tell you what, while the enemies are generally a joy most of the time because of their well designed AI and tendency to tactics and team work that always keep you on your toes,(which I like... Alot!), The Metastreumonic are different. They bum rush you with as many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ creatures that they have on standby and just.. keep.. on... coming!! NO PUN/INUENDO INTENDED!!!They're annoying, They're difficult in large numbers,(which they will always be in large numbers. accept that now my little newbies.), and they are just uneccesary in this game.So after all of this, you would be thinking that I wouldn't recommend this game right?Well you would be wrong. Dead wrong.While I don't play this game as much as I do other games, this is still one of the best games I have ever played in my entire life. I started out with all the negatives, not because I hate this game, but because I wanted to let you, dear noobs, know what you were getting into. While E.Y.E. has some very strong downsides, It's positives more than make up for that.For instances, Character building.Oh my GAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAWD the character building in this game is nigh perfect! Hell, at the very beginning of the game, you get to choose what genes you have in your brian, (WHICH IS VERY IMPORTANT BTW!!), for it affects what your character can do in the game. And as I stated before up above, the possibilities of combat are damn near endless. there's almost nothing you can't do in this game! you want to run and gun your enemies with Matrix like finesse, Go for it! you want to tank up and mow your foes like a bloody lawnmower, Do it! If you want to hack your enemies into joining your side or even control their body movements have at it! You want call upon the very fabric of space and time and use your mystical psychic powers to summon forth clones of yourself while you make your strongest foes explode and turn into a horrific lovecraftian beast that drives your enemies insane as you and your clones cleave and gun down fleeing foes... IF THAT'S YOUR FETISH!! And those four things are just the tip of the ice burg!With LOTS of patience effort, you can do all kinds of things that you could only dream of and become a freakin' battle god/goddess! And speaking of battle, combat in this game is on point! Pending on how high your accuracy is, (if you're like me you don't have to worry about that! >:3), you can pretty much nail enemies with pinpoint accuracy and slaying foes is always satisfying! weapon's are usually a joy to use and there are many of them to choose from!And don't even get me started on the cybernetic enhancements and implants! though pricey and require some grinding to use, I find Cybernetics in this game to be handled very well and it always makes me feel like a total badass when I use them! I mean, Cybervision to see enemies in the dark or to make them more visible, Sound triangulation to found out where moving/talking enemies are on the map, even a freaking cloaking device that renders you almost completely invisible! It feels like I'm from Ghost in the Shell!With that being said, E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy at first may seem like a very intimidating game and very broken to it's core. But once you see past those flaws, You'll find that this game has many redeemable qualities and is very close to being a perfect cyberpunk game that, if you're still interested in, deserves a total recommendation.Give it a shot! ^^𝘓𝘓𝘓𝘓𝘓𝘈𝘛𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘈𝘏𝘚!!!

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												If Cyberpunk is currently your thing and Half-Life's Source Engine has always been your thing: then I think you are probably going to find E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy to be a very interesting game. If a Cyberpunk, FPS/RPG, with some of the most ♥♥♥♥ed up achievements aren't enough to entice you to play this game, then I don't know what will.My friend is a really big Cyberpunk fanatic and one day, he started showing me his progress in the game and I have to be honest - the Source Engine was noticable (almost straight away), but I feel like that isn't a bad thing, since it adds unique features, such as: a few RPG Elements (Levelling-Up, Research/Skills and Stats, Purchasing Item...), Psi Force (A variety of mental/phsycic powers: sort of acts as the games Magic system), Not only is it a Dark Cyberpunk world, but you can get really cool Augmentations/Upgrades for your character! (Enhance your Vital Organs, Limbs, Nerves, Skeleton, Natural Resistence and much, much more). The GENERAL combat system is what you'd expect from a Source Engine-based game, however; the extra features, selection of weapons, qwerky stat system, Psi Force abilities and the option to enhance your body with augmentions, just makes the combat a lot more vercetile, than any FPS or RPG that I have ever played.Oh yeah, EXPLODING MELEE WEAPONS - 93/100!

Posted: June 16, 2015
												The game is a horrible mess of a weird♥♥♥♥♥plot, odd translations, weird mechanics, lack of any real direction initially, and a horrible unuser friendly way of getting any multiplayer games going.The game is a joyous empowering romp through hundreds of enemies warhammer style, with tight first person shooter/hack n slash gameplay, with gorgeous cyberpunk graphics, and a philosophical tale that will make even the most studied scholar scratch his head, and rpg elements that feeling meaningful and non hindering to the gameplay.Expect to be lost, confused, amazed, frustrated, unstoppable and hopeless. When you finnaly understand what the game is you will become addicted to the lore and gameplay in such a way you may never feel like you will understand it all but at the same time feel like you uncovered some weird secret to life.Buy it if you are open minded, not expecting fallout/deus ex, and don't need closure.

Posted: November 28, 2016
												EYE: Divine Cybermancy is one of the most f*cking out-there games I've ever played. No, scratch that; it's the most out-there game I've ever played, by far. I remember reading somewhere that one or more of the developers of this game at Streumon Studios suffers from schizophrenia, which would make sense, because if I had to choose one single word to describe this game, it would be "schizophrenic".An absolutely gut-bustingly hilariously bad translation from French makes the balls-to-the-wall crazy plot of Jians vs Culters vs Feds vs bandits vs hyperdimensional aliens (?? maybe? I think????? I've played this game several times but I'm still not 100% sure), set in the darkest, grittiest Sino-Japonic-influenced cyberpunk setting I've ever experienced (seriously, the atmosphere rivals Snow Crash) and an insane variety of gameplay mechanics that all mesh together in an extraordinarily well-balanced and thought-out way, extensive replayability despite only a dozen or so maps, a choose-your-own-adventure "plot" with multiple endings, and brouzouf for days (JUST GAIN SOME YOU DOUBLE JIAN), and the ability to literally get combat-induced PTSD, all come together to assuredly make EYE hands-down one of my favorite games ever.In short, if you like cyberpunk, bad English, good gameplay, and insanity, EYE: Divine Cybermancy is most undoubtedly for you.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2013
												Imagine playing a lot of Deus Ex and S.T.A.L.K.E.R, ingesting illicit substances, knocking yourself out, and living in a terrifying dreamland for the next 24 hours. That dream would be E.Y.E: The Divine Cybermancy.  You play as a psychic cyborg space marine who has the power to jump several stories in the air, turn invisible, hack computers, clone himself instantly, and much more. If you want, you can sneak around levels stealthily and backstab enemies, or you can put on heavy armor and blow everything up with a minigun. Enemies still overpowering you? Use your psychic powers to drive them insane with hallucinations. If none of those work, you can remotely hack any computer on the level, including the cyborg brains of humans, and then mind control everyone. Once you hack someone's brain, you can see the world through their vision and give them commands. They'll struggle against your control, but if you keep mashing the "attack" button then sooner or later they'll kill all of their friends for you. Be careful, because any of these techniques can be used against you too. Invisible assassins can snipe you. Psychic monsters can empty your sanity meter, causing you to see imaginary enemies and explosions everywhere. If you chose to hack an enemy, their computer can load a counter virus and blow up your cyberbrain.As the plot develops, you slowly realize that your secret organization, the Secreta Secretorum, is wrapped up in a multilayered conspiracy bent on controlling all of society. Depending on the choices you make, you may learn that someone has been pulling the strings on all of the game's mysterious events, or you may discover that you're mind is being manipulated and nothing you've seen is real. Perhaps the entire game is only a recurring dream inside your character's mind. The truth may or may not be revealed in the end.I haven't even mentioned a lot of the other surreal aspects of it. Up to 32 people can play together in the campaign at once. About half of your dialog options will tell characters to ♥♥♥♥ themselves. Occasionally, after shooting someone, the game will inform you that you just killed a loving and caring daddy. You can use x-ray vision to shoot people through walls, make werewolves explode out of people, goomba-stomp people, deflect oncoming bullets with your katana, and at any time you can open a menu to research things XCOM-style. But even though you can assign a hundred scientists to analyze an eyeball you just found on the ground, you never even see a laboratory in the game.Unfortunately, the game suffers from many bugs and other issues which can make it frustrating for new players. It doesn't start you with any of the powers that make the game fun, and you have to grind for a lot of money to unlock them. Objectives often don't make sense, and the levels are huge, so finding the one thing you need can be frustrating. Even just navigating the main hub can be a chore. However, if you can get past all of that and enjoy the core of the game, then it's a ton of fun.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												A lot of people say E.Y.E. is "flawed" and that is has "unrealized" potential. However, this implies that E.Y.E., bugs and unintended glitches aside, did not turn out the way the developers intended it to be. That's not really the case. I think a lot of misunderstandings  about E.Y.E. stem from the fact that a lot of people misunderstood what E.Y.E.is supposed to be. If for some reason you really want to understand the mentality that spawned E.Y.E. and why it is the way it is, here's my suggestion. Install Half-life 1 and play it if you haven't already, then play a bit of Sven Co-op. Then once this is done, go install the HL1 mod "Syndicate Black Ops". This mod was actually created by the devs of E.Y.E. and is it's predecessor for most intents and purposes.  After that, go play E.Y.E. again. There is a good chance that E.Y.E. will suddenly make sense, and its intentions will probably turn out to be not quite as lofty as you might have thought. E.Y.E. is not Deus Ex, STALKER, Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines, and it was never meant to be. It sort of reaches in that direction but it stems from a different place. The notion that E.Y.E. was supposed to be like one of those games was shot down by the devs early on, but people wanted a game like that so badly they were willing to believe that it was one of those games anyway and so eventually they just rolled with it. E.Y.E. comes from an alternate world where games like Deus Ex, System Shock 2, and STALKER became huge successes and sold as much as CoD does in our world. It has RPG mechanics, various tools, a hacking system, inventory management, leaning, and all the sorts of mechanics we associate with a more "sophisticated" game, but these are just a means and in this case they are not matched with "sophisticated" ends.  In this case, they are all here to further the objective of "killing tons of enemies" and "being a badass".E.Y.E. has respawning enemies because if they didn't respawn you'd run out of enemies to kill. Stealth is not fleshed out because stealth is not intended as a gameplay approach by itself, it's just another tool to help you kill more enemies, and in this case it works quite well. Hacking lets you do all sorts of interesting things, but it's also meant to be just another tool you use to be a badass killing machine and is not its own separate play-style. The cybernetic and magic themes are not there to provoke deep thought, they're there just for flavor and to cram in more abilities to make you a badass killing machine. If that's not enough gameplay for you by itself then you're probably going to hate the game because that's what the gameplay is and for better or worse that's what it intended to be. The game was mad by and for people who find this sort of play to be satisfying. The confusing plot that people like to speculate about is just the icing on the cake and excuse to have the sorts of weird locations and maps the game has. It has a story of course but again it's mostly there to justify sending the player to odd places. The game has magical werewolves and space stoner hippies, that should have clued people in that this isn't a super-serious plot or setting. There's a random guy in one of the levels who's depressed and you can talk him into incinerating himself. He doesn't exist to change anything, he's there for the ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles. That's a pretty good summary of how "serious" or "deep" the plot is meant to be. Anyway, there's my review of E.Y.E., interpret that how you will.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
With a very special thanks to RoosterTheRed for proof-reading this review, E.Y.E is a first-person shooter roleplaying game set in a futuristic society in which several factions compete for resources and overall control. You play as a custom character comprised of a chosen set of skills, races, and equipment; as with many other roleplaying titles, these attributes can be altered during the game’s course. Though complex in the beginning, E.Y.E delivers a fantastic overall theme that only enhances the gameplay and in-game decisions. This game includes solo, cooperative, and competitive play options, though it is recommended to play this game with friends or other individuals you know given the fact that the online community is quite scarce in number; this should not be too much of an issue since the base game presents a wide array of playability.Here are just a few things I found of interest in Blat-Blat: Sneaky Shiz (inside joke):Roleplaying Aspects - Within E.Y.E’s in-depth theme, described more thoroughly in a further segment) is the ability to generate and decide conflicts as a character of your choosing. There are multiple humanoid racial archetypes you can choose from, and three can be selected in any combination to grant favored bonuses; a guide is heavily recommended for new players deciding on what race or races to be lest their original tabletop, A.V.A, was reviewed. Beyond this elaborate statistics system in which players can assign skills more pertinent to their style of play by allotting points into such expertise as Hacking. As the player gains levels, they may apportion more points into their skills, and specific upgrades and abilities can be purchased if the player’s character has the prerequisite skill efficiency. Throughout the campaign there are many decisions that can be made to influence the remaining story or side quests, which causes the balance between the multiple existing parties to shift slightly. Another interesting topic is Research, which can be performed from the in-game menu at virtually any time. Research grants the player items such as the healing syringe, as well as additional lore and weapons.Unique Overworld - This title’s theme is widely regarded as steampunk, though I find it to be more reminiscent of Warhammer 40,000’s flavor. Regardless, it maintains a glimpse of a grim future, with rivaling factions, psionic powers, monsters, and magic. Character designs are engaging, and enemy forces are both laughable-referring to the forces with afros-and menacing at times. Scarabs-similar to Skull Servitors in Warhammer 40,000-and other technological advances blend nicely with the atmosphere since a given majority of objects can be hacked or modified. The overworld has a gloomy noir feel to it which amplifies the theme of warring parties while retaining individuality.Gameplay - E.Y.E melds several interesting components together into one combat system which can be experienced in a variety of ways. Items are displayed in an overly of the character in a depiction as to what they can carry in a grid-based format; this generally means that you can bear as much as can be “on your person.” Gameplay is fluid, with varying forms of firearms and melee weapons at the player’s disposal to aide in eliminating hostiles. The previously described Research system also plays a vital role in weapon selection since weapons and items such as the Gatling gun and medical syringe, respectively, can be developed for use. Players are able to hack objects for certain gains such as opening a secret compartment behind a locked door, and are even able to be hacked back by the object they are targeting; it’s strange but highly humorous. Psionic powers can also be used in combat. Examples of this include creating multiple clones of the player, performing a devastating sprinting melee attack, transmuting all grounded items into health pickups, and passively increasing jump elevation. There are also several purchasable upgrades from venders which add new powers and improve known skills. All of these allow the player to develop their own style of play apart from the usual ‘kill everything that moves and forget anything else’ approach many other first-person shooters adopt.Hidden Content - Though mostly prompted by side missions, there are many undiscovered bounties stowed around the map. One such is a treasure that few players have discovered-including myself-within the vicinity of a huge map. These objectives add a great amount of depth to E.Y.E, as well as replayability.TL:DR - E.Y.E offers an enormous amount of content for players who enjoy roleplaying games and intriguing lore combined with a variety of actions, upgrades, and choices in-game. This title does have its quirks in regards to certain features but its gameplay style makes up for this as a motley roleplaying experience unlike many. This title is highly recommended for those who pursue games that blend tactics and combat, as well as those how persistently go out of their way to unravel secrets. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

												Okay so I got this game when it was 90% off for just $0.99. I excpected it to be one of those, well you know, $0.99 games. Turns out, I was totally wrong.I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game. The aethetic and storyline (to me) is awesome. The coop is great. I love the ideas they implemented into game, things like hacking, psi force, and your character's mental stability. The combat is enjoyable.Now there are a couple of cons. The new things I mentioned, while I like their ideas, I feel like some were implemented poorly, making it less viable to be a certain class, but this is something that doesn't bother me too much, and I don't think it will bother you much either.Personally, I hope one day, one ♥♥♥♥ing day some gaming company sees this and buys the rights to it and makes a sequel. I firmly believe that if a sequel was made and it refined not just the graphics physics engine, and added voice acting, but fully developed the features added to the game, this could easily be GOTY material.Thanks for reading.

												Wonderfully original and mind-boggling.I'm not sure how much of that is due to the poor translation, but if you choose to play this game, know that there is a lot of unexplained information.It's the game that combines religious, military, cyberpunk, and revolutionary themes that I never knew I wanted. Sometimes you feel strong, and other times you feel weak. I was mostly occupied trying to figure out what's going on while I completed objectives, but it all came together for moments that made me feel like I was watching a big movie like Star Wars for the first time.Definitely play this.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												I'll recommend this game, but only if you can get it on a sale of some sort.While the game is a little bit glitchy in terms of saving from time to time, most of the time it holds up really well. After validating, I've only had it crash once. Translations aren't perfect, and some of the words are just really hard to pronounce, much less know how to spell off hand. Though, this isn't really obstructive to gameplay, given you can easily figure things out if you think for a few moments.The game won't tell you all the default keys, you're going to want to check those, as the tutorial isn't going to answer that for you either. The tutorials frankly aren't that beneficial, they'll give you the very basic, but fully employing something is going to take trial and error.Actual gameplay wise... The game is great really, you're not restricted to just being the heavy armored titan who shambles along mowing down everything he sees. Sure, in the beginning you're going to be more or less locked into the basic strategies of, long range versus close range... But very soon, you'll be able to make yourself capable of stealth, tanking, hacking, and more.To explain what I mean to those thinking of buying this game:The game does have a stealth system. It's normally impossible to be stealthy unless you use the cloak implant that you can buy pretty early in. If you hit someone who hasn't detected you, you will get a pretty nicely sized modifier to your hit.Hacking; is actually a very powerful tool in the game if you can get a few good strategies for it going. You can quite literally make your enemies turn against each other, ignore, and even defend you. You can take a glance through someone's eyes... Or you can flat out cause brain death by hacking a person. However, hacking isn't possible on all enemies in the game.There's varieties of every type of gun in the game, each with a unique aspect. Just looking at melee, the Distortion Hammer is big, heavy, slow... But it causes massive damage, and it can work great as a shield (yes, you can block using weapons, bigger weapons are better at blocking). There's also the dual blades, which are fast, lethal, but lack the damage per hit and blocking power of the hammer. In short; you can play it light, quiet and quick... Or big, heavy, and monsterous... With any weapon really.Your "special" stuff doesn't come from killstreaks or anything like that, no, they come from two branches of specials, which are purchasable/earnable. Cyber Implants and Psy Powers. Implants are all purchasable, but psypowers; some are purchasable, others have to be earned.Cyber Implants have mostly basic effects, improving your aim, hardening your skin, making you invisible to enemies, making you jump higher and run faster...Whereas Psy Powers... Are much more specialized. Creating tissue paper clones of yourself to shoot at enemies, turning ammo into health, health into energy, killing and teleporting to your target, among others.Now, the reason why I say that you should buy this game if it's on sale...Is that while it's well made in terms of creating an atmosphere, being unique, and giving you plenty to play with... The actual stuff you'll be fighting.. Is pretty slim in diversity.Sentries, Scrabs, Jiang, Carnophage, Looter, Manduco, Synicle, Federal Cop, Special Force, Deus Ex, Interceptor, Kraak, Perigrum Forma, and Patrol.That is every non-named in the entire game. Which as you can imagine gets pretty repetitive. Different weapons but pretty much the same thing.You can configure AI, but most of the time, enemies seem to be great at finding, and shooting you even from long distances. Even on the lowest "reinforcement" spawn, you might find yourself swarmed with over a dozen of a single enemy, who automatically path towards you from their spawn point just a few feet away. Yes, that is a problem with the game, respawns of enemies are pretty bad. They'll spawn at set points, ones which can be easily memorized given they're largely just open space most of the time, and you can literally walk to that spot... Wait, and then take newly spawned enemies by surprise, mowing them down with ease.Not all gamestyles are that rewarding.If you hack a lot, you'll find you're getting a disproportionate amount of XP to money.If you sneak a lot (ghosting through missions, which is possible nicely enough), you'll find you're low on everything, given there's not much of a bonus to being unseen at all times aside from getting shot less.If you raise a machine army of Scrabs and Sentries... Expect them to die. If a non-machine ally gets hit by one by accident (very easy given sentries are machine guns), they will kill your machine.Ally AI is pretty bad, you'll find yourself getting trapped in corners and in hallways by allies who don't realize you trying to walk through them is a cue to move out of the way... And often times, when they do move, they'll move just to get in your way again, because you found a way past them. They're also totally dumb in terms of vision and sound. If they didn't get shot, and they're not looking at whoever's firing dozens of rounds a minute... No matter how many times you get hit, they will not turn around to help you. Your only hope is to just pray they randomly turn in time to help you. Allies especially are pretty bad when it comes to getting in the way of you defending yourself. They are quite literally the last thing you want when you're using a sniper rifle at long range, as they won't hesitate to step in front of you right when you're aiming, or even shooting, causing you to have to move so they're not blocking you anymore... Or just kill them.All in all...The game is a great idea, it's got a great design... But the amount of small things that will make you go, "That's such a simple thing... How could they not get that right? Or at least fix it?" is pretty high in number.  The game does make you think though in terms of strategy, using your environment to your advantage, which is definitely it has going for it. But I digress...Unless you have played it before, or you have cash you're willing to gamble, or it's on sale...Don't buy it.If you end up liking this game, chances are... You will LOVE it. But it really depends on who you are and what you look for in a game. It's not your typical FPS, it's not your typical RPG, it's not your typical anything really. It's a mash of several genres, and while I do love it, and recommend it...I do understand it's not for everyone; the environment/lore might be a turn off for people, or you might find it to enhance the experience. This formula works out for many aspects of the game.... And so like I said;It's one hell of a game. Whether or not you love it, is on you.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												While it may say 42 hours on record, my actual record in E.Y.E is 84. So I think I have enough experience with this game to finally review it.First off, I'm just going to warn future buyers that E.Y.E is a game that appeals to a very specific kind of player, generally players who are fans of the first Deus Ex from 2000's. I had to learn this the hard way after suggesting this to many of my friends only for them to judge the game as broken or unfinished. It's not for everyone, and even though I enjoyed this game I can understand why people don't like it.So what exactly is E.Y.E? E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy is a cyber punk FPS RPG drug trip published and developed by Streum. In E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy you customize your character(s) and shape them into different paths that the game has set for you (and no, you cannot customize your character's gender or body type, it's only on a stat level) The game has quite a learning curve at the very start of the game so when the game throws a needle in your face and tells you to inject yourself full of cybernetic Chi...You pick some traits that sounds cool only to find out you've made the worst character in existance.You can also select different armor types for whatever playthrough you're going with, such as: Light armor, which allows you to run faster and cloak more effectively but very fragile and next to useless at the end game. It's good for a stealth or Psi run if you are sitting on a large amount of stamina, but that's about it. Medium armor, a bit slower than light armor but can take a fair amount of punishment. This armor is decent from early to mid game and sometimes late game depending on what role you went with. But chances are you're going to want heavy armor on mars. And finally Heavy armor, this armor is a little too strong for it's own good. It can tank massive amounts of damage and if you have a chaingun, you might as well be considered a living turret. There isn't a whole lot of mobs in early to mid game that can potentially stop you other than demons. The only flaw to this armor is it's speed, but when you look at the Heavy armor's benefits, it simply makes the game a whole lot easier to play. The Plot  It's really hard to say what the plot is, or at least where it's going. There are several different theories floating around on the forums and none of which have managed to explain as to what in the hell is going on. You play as some cybernetic ninja/samurai/knight/zombie. And if that hasn't already driven you off then I congratulate you, you are perhaps more devoted to insane indie games than I am.You wake up from some nightmare (or vision) only to find yourself in a cave cluttered with bodies and blood stains. You then recieve a message from your 'Mentor' saying you need to get out of the cave before the federals find you. Once you have arrived at the HQ you will get a lecture from your mentor about how you were captured and a reminder of the curent state of the proxy war with the two factions within E.Y.E, the Jians and the Culter. After your chat with him, you are greeted by some kind of floating metal box with a gun attached saying you left a message for yourself.  You learn that you have amneisa (obviously) and that there was a mission on mars that went to hell and back with you somehow in the mix of it.That's pretty much the easiest to understand. But after that the story itself takes a nose dive into the chaotic storm that is insanity, leaving you with no idea as to what your objective is or why you are doing it.A lot of players claim that's what makes E.Y.E enjoyable, but I had to play the game in small sips because of the garbled plot. So you better like Source engine, shooting the same models of enemies over and over again, and grinding for research items because the story is not worth paying attention to. The Game  I'm not going to lie to you, this game is a fresh breath of air in this MoBA/action shooter dominated industry. This game does a good job of creating a unique Cyberpunk setting despite being limited by the constraints of the Source engine. And if there is another E.Y.E installment, I would prefer it still used Source simply because it seems to work well with the game. You also have the advantage of anyone on a potato could play it. But there are many problems with E.Y.E that make it hard to create an enjoyable experience. First of all the guns and the way they feel are horrible. This is once again, probably because of the Source engine because so far I have yet to play a Source game with satisfying gunplay. The other flaw with guns is the progression (or the progression of this game in general) in which they are unlocked. The majority of them are already unlocked and most of the default weapons are far better than what you can purchase (excluding the power hammer and the Bear Killer) I'm not sure what the development was like for this game, but this is basic progression logic completely ignored.Finally the maps- The true problem with the maps in E.Y.E is just the emptiness, there aren't any civilian NPC's (no I am not counting the bandits as civilian NPC's) Without civilians walking around it just takes away the atmosphere. It's that hateful moment when you stop and think "oh yeah, I'm in a video game..." Hell, there's even a map called New Eden where you can run into apartments and quickly find out that there is no living human being in a single room.Speaking of human population, if you aren't fond of the whole "women as trophies" thing then you are not going to like any mission involving bandits. Because a large portion of their quests involve stealing sex slaves or some rubbish like that. Ironically, there are no in-game female models, they are only mentioned....So as far as you know you're stealing nothing but a poor man's depraved wet dream. Have FUN!And lastly the multiplayer. The multiplayer is really disappointing simply because there are only two game modes and next to no population playing them. The first game mode is Battle Royale where you spawn in the map with a random selection of armor and weapons, there is also perma death so caution rewards. The next game mode is a little bit different, you take a spiked orb from one side of the map to the other with your team, so death basket ball royale to be frank. This game mode unfortunately only has about 2 or 4 maps and zero population playing it. So Co-op is really where this game's strength is, but I still consider PVP as content so I'm including it in the review. Final Verdict  There is a lot more to cover but some of it could potentially spoil the game or turn you off completely. So my rating for E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy is a 7/10! The game offers a lot of choices but ironically doesn't allow you to pick a side between Culter and Jians, or develop your character's personality. But what really ruins the experience is the plot itself. If the game kept a plot and ran with it instead of sending you off on a wild goose chase, I might have been easier on it. But that would have to be my biggest complaint with E.Y.E.However, E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy is reasonably priced at $9.99 and even lower on sales ($2.99 or $0.99) so if you don't enjoy it you won't be horribly punished by your purchase. But between the limits of the Source Engine and the lack of experience with game progression it's understandable why some people would call this unfinished. I cannot blame anyone for saying so, but I also cannot agree that this game is worthless. So a 7/10 would have to be the best I can award it without being too biased.

Posted: April 6, 2016
												E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is a shooter with one of the most interesting setting I have ever seen in a video games, and it has an amazing atmosphere too! While the writing is really bad, it doesn't get in a way too much and the story can be ignored. While the game is just decent in singleplayer, E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is probably the best co-op multiplayer shooter I have ever played. It's not just about shooting too, as players can use various PSI abilities and other kinds of skills too. I recommend getting it with friends to play together. However, if you have no friends, then it's pretty good too, albeit you will miss the strongest point of the game.

Posted: October 27, 2014
												EYE is one of those few games that leaves me severely wanting more but is also almost perfect the way it is. The almost is there because there are some annoying bugs, and you may need to do what I did which is backup the save files every time you exited due to some of the bugs. There was one stage in particular that gave me a great deal of grief, but the elements were there, especially the hacking, and the story kept me interested too. It's true, the story will not make sense even if you do get the 'true' ending, but it's possible to piece together some idea of a story which has worked for games like Killer 7 or Hotline Miami. If you like reading into things and speculating about story, it will probably capture you too. Just look into those bugs and back up from the beginning.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2011
												The trailers suggest that EYE is an indie Deus Ex, allowing varied playing styles. Sadly this isn’t true. It’s combat heavy with constantly respawning enemies. The cloak runs out too quickly, the maps are huge with wide open spaces and not enough cover, to make stealth a viable tactic. The plot doesn’t make sense to me, partly due to a poor translation from the native French language resulting in NPC dialogue lacking proper grammar, and partly because allies give updated orders during missions while you’re too busy trying to not die, so it’s hard to concentrate on what is being said, and every mission becomes a case of just following the waypoint marker and shooting some guys or pressing a button without ever really knowing why. Yes, there are some complex character stats and abilities and the shooting is okay, but nowhere near as entertaining as Serious Sam for mindless violence. Ultimately I can only recommend EYE on a Steam sale if you’ve got nothing better to play.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												It's been a while since I last reviewed a game on Steam - or anywhere else for that matter - and to break this trend I decided to write up some of my experiences with the things I've been playing. As a bonus, I will try to make use of the text formatting that has been introduced by Steam in the meantime.IntroductionFirst up on that list is E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy (abbreviated as EYE from here on), an FPS/RPG crossover made by the relatively unknown ‘Streumon Studio’, which should sound familiar if you have played the Half Life 1 total conversion mod called ‘Syndicate Black Ops’. On a sidenote here: people have been notifying me that some of the games I write about are rather old and as such my efforts might not be read by anyone. I’m fully aware of this and it is no problem to me. Some games stand the passing of time well and others even manage to become more appealing as they age, a phenomena caused by nostalgia and the fact that this industry is being saturated by bad titles.MeritI would consider EYE one of the latter category. While it is certainly not ugly, I wouldn’t dare call it a beautiful game either. A disadvantage with realism as far as graphics are concerned is that they do not measure up to titles that release later on. Of course that’s an unfair comparison, but it’s one that will be made regardless. Games like World of Warcraft that go for the full comic book style graphics can sport ‘kiddy’ visuals for years to come, but has it done their setting any justice? Only a fanboy would concur. Instead, realistic graphics has to come with dramatization in order to increase the shelf like for the demanding gamer. The most obvious examples would be the brilliant bloom effects in Lineage 2’s Angel Waterfall, the gold shaders in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, or the blend of drawings with old graphics used in the Mount & Blade series. While EYE has constituted their theme pretty well, the use of some low resolution textures and models here and there can still break the immersion. That aside, it’s a very good effort that is very commendable, especially during the dream and certain parts of the HQ. In fact, in some parts it's quite extreme, think of huge power cables running through the streets and even fighting on Mars.The strength of EYE definitely appears to be the character customization but the sounds and shooting mechanics are actually more fleshed out. At first this might seem like an odd thing to say as there are many powers and augmentations to choose from, however, as you progress through the levels you will come to find that specializing your character in a specific playstyle does not pay off. With the current state of the variables it is much more viable to build a generic tank/gunner as  the other powers are either too taxing or influence your character too little to make much of a difference in battle. My character is currently level 40+ and having failed to be a drone master – since every enemy in the game gets tougher and my drones only gained a one time marginal HP increase and cannot be replenished during firefights – I noticed that straightforward upgrades related to gun performance and health will give you better results. It’s rather sad, but I understand that these niche playstyles are uncommon so they are represented less.Last, but not leastIf you read my reviews before you will probably be wondering why I haven’t mentioned anything about the storyline yet, the reason for that is that I can’t. The storyline isn’t bad, just very complicated! I will really need to finish a couple more playthroughs to really get the gist of it. In conclusionAll in all, E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy is a well designed game assuming a setting that is underrepresented in comparison to other themes. If you enjoy cyberpunk then you have probably come at the right address, though keep in mind that the theme is anything but subtle and the customization could be better.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												So let's try writing some review for these games I have. Anyways,E.Y.E. You're a stupidly wierd game.Good:The gameplay is fun for what it is, and I never got tired of the cool factor of being able to block machine gun fire with my sword or being able to hack into someone's skull to make them explode. Couple of other gadgets you start with too, and you have quite a few upgrades and new guns you can get that may or may not be fun to use. It never really gets painfully hard either, which I consider a redeeming factor for this incoherent game.There are plenty of free missions and locales that you can play, several fun to use weapons, pyschic powers, a campaign that doesn't overstay it's welcome, and an awesome atmosphere that is both tense and unsettling. The entire setting has a nice cyberpunk feel to it, and there's plenty of cool factor to spare.Bad:If you are expecting any kind of story to enjoy than good luck. Confusing English and a lack of explanation makes the story hard to follow at best. It doesn't help that the story plays with some insanity tropes as well; making things even more confusing. The rpg mechanics are worthless, and I never really felt like I became anything special aside from just a samurai guy. Some of the systems like magic/psychic power feels underdeveloped, and the insanity thing, which actually is an interesting mechanic for the game, can be removed by an 'upgrade'. As far as combat goes: the A.I. is ridiculous. One little detection can result in the entire enemy army walking in a straight line towards your location. There is also this weird critical hit/negative hit system, but I've killed enemies in one hit with a "Failed Attack" several times so I don't know what to make of that. Overall, The whole thing just feels marred by poor design choices.The story is confusing as a story can get. The core rpg mechanics lack complexity. There are way too dang many large empty areas. A.I. is clumsy at best. And you'll probably go through the whole game without buying or upgrading anything. Don't expect to be impressed anywhere here; there's just a lot of boring trash beneath a paper thin shine.Overall:It's a game you have to play simply for the experience. Just to play for the overall unique strangeness of the setting. To get sucked in to the weirdness of the story about a cybernetic super samurai who may or may not be insane. It has it's cool moments to help things a long too, and to say again, you start with a sword that can block pretty much anything and sets people on fire.But, if you are expecting a solid experience then you probably won't be amused by this at all. The game requires you to overlook a lot of problems. If it were even a little bit better I would change my overall opinion here. But there is just nothing to guarantee you will like this, so that's why I would not recommend it.

												Where to ♥♥♥♥ing start?Okay, the reason I am recomending this game is not necessarily because it has the capacity to be enjoyable, which it totally does, but because this game is just so ♥♥♥♥ing weird that I like it, or I hate it, I'm not quite sure. It is a game that defies criticism and defies review.The game is absolutely littered with problems and it isn't really designed spectacularly well, yet, just look at it, look at it, with your face, use your eyes and see the mess that is this game. I feel like I am going crazy here. Am I the only one seeing this? They literally included 32 player co-op as a thing because... why the ♥♥♥♥ not? It totally breaks the game but have it anyways.This is probably the most horrifying thing I have ever played and it isn't trying to be a horror game, it has given me nightmares since I bought it over a year ag because I have literally had panic attacks while playing this game. One of the bullet points on the steam page says, "Psychological and mental trauma management," which is totally meant as like a feature of the game but it really means the mental and psychological trauma this game will cause you, in real life, to your sanity. I think I have enough evidence to file for psychological abuse.You may think I meant for this to be a would not recomend review but no, I totally 100% recomend this game. I sincerely believe everyone should buy and play this game. You just have to see this♥♥♥♥♥♥ it is truly baffling. It's bad but it's good, it's really good. It's a world you will keep coming back to because you want to try to understand it, but you won't, you won't understand it. I know, I've played it. This game is, to me, an example of what all sci-fi should aspire to be, a complete non-sensical mess that gives you more questions than answers.Oh and I guess there is multiplayer now.TL;DR - Panic Attack Simulator 2011 GOTY edition

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												This is an RPG combined with FPS.It has some great ideas, but they're hard to spot because of overall crudeness.First and the most annoying: it's dark. Too dark. Unless you're walking with your eye implant always on - you can't see a thing.Second: lack of descent tutorial and explanation. Here, have this complex game, figure out by yourself how to enjoy it.Third: I understand that devs wanted to force players to use tactics other than brute force... Well, it's great for hardcore players and all, but there is a huge downside: if you don't know beforehand which tactics you need to use to win this mission, you'll fail. More than once.Fourth: and here we arrive to ridiculous saving system. Your progress is saved. All the time. But every time you're brought back to the last checkpoint (these are VERY rare). For example: I talked with Mentor during the mission, got a ton of exp, disconnected... Resumed the game and I can talk to Mentor once more to gain ton of exp once more. I just happened to do that 5 or so times.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												The game struck me a cross between Ghost in the Shell and Deus Ex fighting in Total Recall.There is a great deal of build customization to suit your playstyle from jaunting sniper to ogre brute with a sword. The tutorial is not very helpful at all. If you don't like trial and error tinkering you should probably go straight to a guide for mechanics and loadout.I enjoyed the game for its novelty and variety of playstyles but ultimately abandoned it. For some reason any lenghty gameplay sessions left me with some annoying headaches (literally, not sure if it was the lighting or the movement).I can't really recommend this game unless your a big fan of the dystopian sci-fi genre or are looking for something different to play and want something like Fallout in an Unreal Tournament world with tighter gunplay and less need for talking.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												Many people buy this game thinking they're buying a System Shock or a Deus Ex. Maybe a Borderlands or a STALKER. This is an incorrect assumption to make. It's true that EYE features many RPG elements. It has dialogue, branching paths, levels, inventory management, stores and side-missions. But this is all plays second fiddle to what EYE is really aiming for. It's not a Deus Ex as much as it is a Serious Sam. It's not a Borderlands as much as it is a Painkiller. I really cannot emphasize this enough, it's my belief that the majority of the complaints directed towards EYE stem from a false presupposition of what this game is trying to be. That is not the players fault though, because EYE doesn't exactly make these things clear.EYE is a mess.Unless you are a Dwarf Fortress player, EYE is likely to be the biggest, messiest game you are ever likely to see. Right off the bat it gives you a character creation screen which makes absolutely no sense to anyone beginning the game without first googling what in the hell you are looking at. The dialogue is either intentionally vague, bizarre and most of the time incomprehensible. You will be thrown into a world which appears to have some sort of lore and backstory but you'll be lucky if you ever understand a tenth of what is going on. When the game presents you with the tutorial level, many aspects of that tutorial will need tutorials themselves, and you will be confronted with a library of tutorial videos on how certain game mechanics work. Your body can be hacked and destroyed by doors and ATMs. Sometimes huge monsters will appear in the level and fire rockets in directions you didn't even know existed and you have to kill it. Sometimes you'll be tasked to kill a high ranking enemy and he will zip about the game shooting and cloaking tanking hits like nothing else. This game is primarily single-player, but you can have 64-player coop. You can buy spells and augmentations and guns and big hammers all with a currency called Brozouf which you seem to endlessly gain in areas where you are doing something for some reason for someone. EYE is a deranged and twisted mess of Syndicate, Neuromancer, Warhammer 40k and the entire personal drug stash of Hunter S. Thompson. And you know what? It's amazing.There is no messing around with regenerating health, cover or killcams. You can go in fast and furious or heavy like robocop. The guns feel like they should. There is real impact when you shoot something. Enemies will go flying across the screen. You can teleport into people and laugh as they explode. You can hit people in the face with giant hammers and watch as they bounce off the walls. You can hack people. You can force push four-armed creatures into radioactive goo. You can block bullets with swords. This game can be anything you want, but above all it is satisfying. If you get this game, it's imperative that you know what you getting into. If you want a cyberpunk dystopia with thought provoking dialogue and choices that mean something, I don't advise you to get this game. If you want a crazy FPS that is a completely unapologetic mess that explains nothing but offers everything then I would strongly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												A delicious game that took many by surprise, E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is one of those purchases that will keep you coming back for more.What you need to know:Amazing use of the Source engine, sporting great visuals and environments.  Even the weapons have several animation states!Sounds are pleasing, and the soundtrack is VERY pleasing.  (Though, you will have to dig into the game files to grab the music.)Melee weapons, handguns, rifles, shotguns, high-explosives, and even a hammer.  Not to mention crazy psychic voodoo-magic.  Also you can clone yourself, and your clones will even level up based on your stats, as well.Some great, uh, voiceacting.  Trust me, you'll find it quite amusing at times.Gameplay is excellent.  Hacking is a challenge, and the gunplay is satisfying.  Also, you can kill people by throwing hamburger boxes at high speeds and that's funny to me.Standalone missions to play outside of story mode even support randomized enemy spawns, and random-picked objectives.  And to add to that, cooperative mode allows many players to play through the story mode seamlessely.  Lots of achievements, if you're into that.---------------The downsides:A blast in singleplayer, but the game truly becomes a gem with friends.The translation quality on ingame texts is.. err..It can take some time to find the randomly-dropping researches, and money grows on your character a bit slowly.  Dying is EXTREMELY dangerous, as it can apply perma-debuffs to your character's stats.  That is, until you sink enough time and money into research to prevent them entirely.Community for it is a bit stagnant, and while custom maps are possible, pretty much none exist.Multiplayer PVP feels strange, and multiplayer itself has some odd bugs.  IE: Lives are shared across all players, meaning somebody dying multiple times can kick EVERYONE back to the lobby map.  Some maps even end up killing the host when a client dies in some areas.  All physics objects also effect other players, so you CAN kill someone else with a high-velocity object, even if PVP is disabled.  Oh, all NPC's (even friendly ones!) are affected by damage, so it's easy for one player to null-void the entire lobby map of NPC's to buy from.  Ouch.Re-playability tends to DIE after some time of playing it, but it has enough to offer to make you come back after a while as well.  (You'll probably get tons of hours through a single chunk of playing through it all, though.  Even more with friends!)---------------All in all, great game.  REALLY glad I was able to play this, and hope you will too.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												This game is hard to get into, hard to master, and for most people the first hours are a real pain in the♥♥♥♥♥. Yes, you´ll either love it or hate it, it´s a very unique game.        <<<<<THE BEGINNING>>>>> You are thrown into a world you probably wouldn´t imagine in your weirdest weed-caused dreams. You are a guy who lost all his memories (yes, this setting is very commonly used;). You make your way out of a dark cave, where you get attacked by the first enemy: a rather small two-legged red monster spitting fireballs. After some minutes in, you realize that somehow the cave leads to the very top of a industrial building used as Military base. You gear up: Double Katanas, Pistols, , Revolvers, MGs, Assault rifles, Sniper Rifles, do you want Armor? A light, medium or heavy one? Drones? Medipacks? Remote Turrets? Grenades?)  You then kill some old-fashioned fallout-like brotherhood-of-steel guys who decided to spend their free time and roam around in a lonely cold wet canal next to the building complex. Jump into the sewers, bash annoying punks there, get out, make an attempt to hack a door but fail desperately the first time, get hacked back by the door as you think                   "What am I doing here?!"  At this point, most people quit the game and uninstall it. E.Y.E makes it very hard for beginners to get into the mechanics, and you have to figure out almost everything by yourself. But after you get used to it, the game is definitely worth your time. There are 10+ unique designed open-world levels you can replay anytime with optional side quests and randomly-generated objectives.          <<<<<GAMEPLAY>>>>> It´s up to you how to beat the level, if you want to go rambo with a minigun, go sneaky with your crysis-like nanotek invisibility suit and kill guys with your bullet-blocking katana, hack enemy turrets  and control them, summon  allied ghostsoldiers, use drones and remote turrets, sniping using infrared vision, bribe NPCs,......<<<<<WEAPONS>>>>>The weapon feel all pretty solid, there is a wide range to choose from. Every weapon has it´s requirements, but once you unlocked it with the in-game currency "bonzoufs", you can equip them for "free". Assault rifles don´t f**** around, they are single-shot at the distance, very accurate and can bring down the early-game enemys with 1-2 shots. Overall well balanced  <<<<<GADGES>>>>>    You can choose from Medipacks, Remote ("Half-Life") turrets, flying drones, and Grenades.Many of these Items have to be researched before you can unlock them at your HQ`s. The best thing is that besides your limited inventory space("System Shock"), there is no limit how many of what things you equip. So if you are a Rambo style player, you might want to get a nice Assault Rifle, double pistols and fill the remaining "backpackspace" with mags.  Items do not cost something to equip, they only have to be unlocked, which gives you a lot of freedom since you don´t depend on money                                        <<<<<STORY>>>>> The Story is very confusing. There are no intro video sequences, you have to figure it out by yourself by either reading 30+ pages of written stuff in your HQ´s libary or search online for a fanmade story intro;). The story is poorly told, but not bad at all. Depending on your choices, there are different endings. (No "Mass Effect endings")The replayability is very high, you can go on side missions, and if you roam around in the levels, there are may people to meet, things to do, equipment to get.... Almost every guy in the game has a quest for you, it´s up to you if you accept it and how you beat it.Also, there are many strange things to discover in this weird world;)   My rating: 8/10, pick it up while on sale, not everybody likes the game;) And please don´t go in and be like "oh, there are soldiers shooting at me. F*** what is he throwing at me? DAAAAMN I got killed.... *uninstall* Give it it´s time! You didn´t explore the van Braun/Majestic 12 HQ´s in one day, did you?PS: read the beginner guides in the forum and play the demo (read them before playing the demo;)[If you think I have not mentioned important facts/ have suggestions to edit the review, please comment] -carrot/eM

												In my highschool P.E. class we would go to the local bowling alley sometimes. We would take the school's bus and my friend would always sit in the same exact seat. The seats were made of foam and covered in a fake-leather material. My friend would always poke at a tear on the seat in front of him, but I initially thought nothing of it. This is important.The bowling alley had a food court near the entrance with a bunch of packets of condiments. My friend would always grab a handfull or two of them and stuff them into his pockets on the way out. One day back on the bus I noticed my friend poking at the hole on the seat again, and he started emptying into it  the contents of the mayonaise and ketchup packets he took from the bowling alley.I asked him what he was doing and he only said, "It's the sauce hole."Also E.Y.E. is pretty good.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												This thing is completely strange. It's a source engine shooter that has an "A" typical dystopian cyberpunk setting blended with Warhammer 40K with a bit of French-sounding VO. You are given a smorgasbord of powerful weapon options from the get go in the tutorial. There are a multitude of separate character upgrade paths that are impenetrable without some research (including research as one of the paths). Missions are semi-labyrinthian style maps with re-spawning enemies. Some are huge. You can alter the difficulty AI, and respawn rates in the options on the fly at any time. There is no manual save...auto save by way of a character profile. You can take your character online, offline, coop, and in-between independent from the single player campaign. There's a hacking mini-game with 4 different starting options and an additional layer of 5 options during the hack. There's over a dozen Cybernetic upgrades and implants and PSI powers (like Magic) on top of all that. It is a bit overwhelming with so many options. The game isn't without its host of problems but suffice is the say I love games that confuse me and challenge the norm. Recommended if you want something woefully different.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												I'll be frank...this game has a lot of potential. Its only real draw to me is it's like Deus Ex... if Deus Ex was a horribly translated, pretty shotty source mod and hadn't been funded by some pretty large companies at the time. That being said, what there is to the game is fun. E.Y.E. boasts nice multiplayer, interesting leveling systems, a cool crafting system but is plagued with issues like limited enemies and the quickly dying out source engine. As much as source has brought us joy and happiness, it just isn't modern game material, even back in 2011.With all of those factors in place, the enemies can be ridiculously easy, often running around randomly into tactically horrid spots. The hacking in the game is another game to its self, like a small RPG that is played in a minute or so. The Tutorials are also extremely lengthy, have no sound, and because of the communication gap caused by the games horrible translation, hard to follow. The story is told to you through your collegues and mentors since you for some reason have amnesia, which is one drawn out story mechanic this game could have done without. Overall the game is a fun tech demo, if source wasn't already out for almost a decade, I would have been wow'd by this. It's a good buy if you can get it for $5 or less, but definitely isn't worth the $10 price tag.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												E.Y.E is not a game for the light-hearted, but can easily be fun when you have a solid grip on it's mechanics. If you're just starting out, you'll notice there is a fairly large and extensive RPG element despite this being an Action/FPS title. Do not be overwhelmed! This game is simply trying newer things and mixing up the genre a bit. You can use money you've gained to research new weapons, better abilities, and better cybernetic implants. Your character slowly becomes this god-like being whether you just want to run'n'gun or be more ninja like. Either way, what's infront of you usually dies. A very ambitious title.Not to mention that there are branching story archs.The artwork and design is a well blended cluster of Warhammer meeting Cyber-Punk. The weapons feel heavy and powerful. The cities have smog and droopy colors. Everything comes together really giving the world this depressing "hell was already here" look. Sadly, the Source engine begins to show it's age. That didn't stop the great map development or modelers though. Bugs tend to still pop up and physics can go haywire, but that has not stopped me from enjoying 200+ hours of entertainment. I bought this years ago and still enjoy it. Even if it isn't on sale, I would recommend this game. I can only pray for a solid sequel. I even see this on sale for $1 USD every now and again. Don't let the price tag fool you. It's way beyond a bargain (if you're willing to let go of what you already knew about the FPS genre).Get it.Love it.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
This review presumes you already read other stuff about this game."Heavy is good, heavy is reliable. If it doesn't work, hit them with it"And oh, how heavy is this game.Fristly, i'd like to say that i watched an entire PT on this game before buying it. Don't take my 8 hours of GP seriously.The essencial about this game is covered pretty much everywhere, i won't go over it again. I'd like to add, however, that calling it "batshit crazy", "old tech", "flawed gem", "a mix of deus ex,warhammer 40k" or whatever is to sell this game short. I will discuss about how this game plays and then about how it feels.The gameplay itself is quite simple. It is heavy and reliable. No fancy cutscenes, no quick time events, no nothing. mechanically wise you can buy this game for its face value, there is nothing hidden here. Or at least not in the game itself. You see, this is very true to the 90's fps in this sense. Wanna take cover? you have to actually move yourself behind the wall. Wanna dodge something? good luck with WASD keys. Wanna hit a moving target? (oh they move fast) Gotta train it for good, and the game gives you all the time in the world... for training at least. This game requires some very raw skills kinda forgotten since modern FPS style. If you are 25 YO or older, you already know where i am going with this, if you are younger, this could be a very intresting experience.Some say this game is not an fps, but an RPG with fps elements. Maybe, maybe not. For all i care this is irrelevant. What matters is that you will end up shooting sooner or later. And shooting here is so tight that i could lick my guns to polish it with a blanket after each mission. It feels so damn good! i had actually grown emotionally attached to the guns i use often, hell, i might even start giving them names. The AI has an attention span of a golden fish, true... they are♥♥♥♥♥♥ But somehow this doesn't bother me. It actually makes the game play nice. About how it feels: heavy, solid, yet... oniric.It is very half-life ish when we talk about feelings here. You know, that brutal immersion those games offered us. The way you interact with the world helps a lot in this sense, but there is something more about it. The level design, the neo-noir main approach and the art style walk the lore talk, it feels coherent. You feel a growing confusion about what is happening, you feel so... alone. This provides a most unique immersion for the player, and if you are a social freak like me, you will end up addicted to it very quickly and very strangely. This feeling when you are sneaking around to find some advantage and you spot an enemy. "oh, so this is where you stand... now- where are you going?". This game gives you all the time in the world, and it feels... yeah, it surely feels. In some aspects, this is better here than in, let's say, DE:HR or even than MD, being slightly pushed back by the forseeable AI.Tl;DR: If you are a millenial or older, this neo-noir Diesel punkish looking game feels strangely familiar, and it just might warm your heart with it's cold dark atmosphere.ps: don't try to make sense out of the main plot. There is none to be found.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I am so happy that I came across this game. It literally personifies everything I love about action-adventure RPG's. A perfect hybrid of modern shooters with an inventory development system, point distribution and augmentation / booster system as a in-game mechanic for maxing one's toon. Using a punishment system where even the most fatal of deaths can make a perma-dip in hardstat, this game forces the player into researching and mastering skills and cybernetics to become a literal God. A glorious hub world, endless skirmish content, a story driven expirience with a dash of sword and board / shootem-up gives me the desire to log back in something serious, sometime soon.Using the source engine, supporting multiplayer porting and massive explorations Id recommend this game to everyone. Badge and achievement progression for the farmer in all of us. Play this game, and begin the spiral decent into madness when we ask ourselves "When is modifications going to far?"Not bad on the eyes for the date released, and OMG the replayability. So good.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
												It's fair to say I love this game. It's a true gem, a diamond in the rough. When I first tried to play it, I couldn't get into it at all. I got my legs broken, I gained no brouzoufs, I couldn't do diddly squat. I abandoned it, thinking it was an awful game.But then I returned, spurred on by people saying that actually, it's a pretty good game. And this time when I played it, I found they were absolutely right. EYE is an acquired taste. A buggy and broken mess of a game that does enough things right to make up for its plethora of problems. A game with a plot so ridiculous yet fascinating when you get invested, with characters that can come back to life as the plot demands. EYE should not be nearly as good as it is.If you've never touched this game before, or you've tried to and hated it, try finding yourself a nice guide on character creation and abilities. Before long, you will become a walking tank with electronic warfare capabilities, invisbility screens, psychic powers, and carrying miniguns, small nuclear cannons, or a revolver that can kill God. If you put in the effort, if you put in the time, if you manage to invest yourself in EYE, you'll be in for a wonderful experience that you can't quite find anywhere else. Buy it, Play it, Gain Brouzoufs, and make sure your legs are OK.
