content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												When you first play this game...


YouTube™ Video: Well that's about enough life... - JonTron 

			Views: 250,567		

			...for me for one day. *From JonTron's review of Birdemic.*		

Actual Review:This game is very fun to play if you can get past all of the problems with the game.Pros: Very nice RPG elements, including skill trees, class systems, character generation, and even a very in depth hacking mini game. Nice gunplay and mostly intelegent AI, including flushing you out, flanking, etc. Lots of replayability due to the many skills and playstyles, (hacker, stealth, running and gunning, etc.) Awesome guns and even a sword that makes stuff explode. Extremely fun multiplayer. Pretty decent music, (but I mean, I couldn't do better).Cons: Really bad translations. Very bad balance between playstyles. It is EXTREMELY confusing to start, and for that reason I recommend reading a character generation guide.I personally think that the pros outweigh the cons, since as long as you can stick with the game it is very fun.Also blood games looks pretty cool, but I wouldn't know.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												So I hear that some people don't like this game, but I don't really understand why. Most likely they're expecting it to be a different type of game, but it's basically an RPG style mod for an FPS game. That's what it is and what it's supposed to be. In my opinion it's pretty successful at this.The main problems with the game are relatively minor, like the font size is too small for modern displays and there's no way to increase it. There are some other minor UI type issues that basicaly seem to stem from the fact that it's an FPS engine mod being sold as a game, and from the fact that the game is a bit dated.The art style in the game is great though. It's basically a combo between the Necromongers from the Riddick movies and the usual cybrpunk stuff (hacking, implants, etc.) The overall level design isn't amazing but it isn't too bad. (It sort of looks like maybe someone designed the levels without too much regard to what quests would be in those levels or how they'd work, then the quest/mission content was added later.) So the levels don't naturally lead you toward quest objectives, but this could be good or bad depening on whether you want your hand held or you want a more realistic experience. (Quest markers exist, but they don't necessarily lead you easily to a waypoint because the actual path you need to take to get there may be kind of convoluted. However there is a "spell" that does pathfinding toward the next quest marker.)In short, it's a unique RPG FPS game with a few rough edges in the UI, and it's kind of dated at this point, but it's cetainly worth picking up especially on sale. If you want CS:GO don't buy it, but if you want a uniqe FPS RPG with a cyberpunk psionic necromonger type theme and don't mind that its an older game then do buy it especially since it's inexpensive.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game is a hybrid of First Person Shooters and Tabletop RPG's. Like a tabletop, you need a little reading, friends and patience to get the fullest out of this game.Conceptually, EYE is basically Deus Ex meets the Imperium of Man. You've got some pretty good gun play, mixed with tabletop conventions like having skill points, rolling critical hits and critical misses, and permanent stat reductions for dying in an embarrassing way.  Like Deus Ex, you can run and gun or stealth your way around the environment, but more akin to tabletops you can also hack other enemies and machines to do your bidding or even be a psychic cyber samurai.As far as I can understand it, the story takes place in a distant far flung future where everything and everyone is computerized to the point where there’s almost no organic madder inside anybody anymore. You work for EYE, a secret agent army working for a mysterious megacorp, fighting against everything from other megacorp armies to the feds (who look like Helghast) to lawless bandits by various means of sabotage, subterfuge and sometimes strait up pop’ in dudes.The entire game can be played in coop for up to 4 players (It’s actually 32 players, but good luck with that) and should very much be played like that. Think of it like D&D, one wizard venturing forth isn’t all that great and pretty hard, but if you have a party of four with varied strengths and weaknesses, you can overcome your enemies as a team.The game may seem overly complex and janky at first, but as you learn your way around and excuse the♥♥♥♥♥♥translation, you’ll have a blast with having cyborg ninja adventures with your friends. Just be careful not to overdose.Here's a mod for a better translationHere's a guide on character generation and mechanics

There's all sorts of neat stuff you can ostensibly do, but when it comes time to actually do it, you'll be too busy blundering about trying to figure out where the ♥♥♥♥ you are, which way to go, and what you're supposed to be doing, let alone what buttons to press or menus to go into, to accomplish much. The rot goes deep; I doubt it's within the reach of any amount of patching to fix. Unless you're really desperate for cyberpunk dystopia, I'd give it a skip.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												I really tried to like this, but it just bored the hell out of me and I couldn't get more than 3 hours or so into it.  The controls are also sloppy, even when I mapped them to my liking, and the perks and leveling system isn't well explained and shrouded in the games lore to its detriment (and researching what things mean in-game is a convoluted chore.  Tooltips would have been awesome).  Maybe the game picks up as you get deeper, but that I may never know (unless I really need to cure a case of bad insomnia).  You're better off just dropping a couple extra bucks and going for Deus Ex:HR.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												This is an interesting game to say the least. Lots of RPG mechanics built into an FPS that uses Half Life gun mechanics. The AI slider bars are pretty innacurate since it seems no matter what you set it to they still see/hear you from a mile away.The multiplayer can be fun but experianced players have an intense advantage over newbies especially if you havent played through the main campaign. The graphic style is interesting and the storyline is actually unique however a lot of the maps ive seen feel empty. The objective system is pretty nice (I personally enjoyed assassination missions) and allows for open ended gameplay.Graphics: 6/10Gameplay: 6/10Story: 6/10Replay Value: 3/10Overall Rating: 4/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												So, this is one of those it's a steam sale and it look interesting buys. As it was only a few dollars and it seemed like something new to play that I might start up every now and again for something new. Starting it up the graphics weren't anything to be thrilled with, but if it's a good game you don't have to have HD textrues. Plus, for a game type like this it's not really needed or the most important quality. Now I want to preface everything in this review with the simple fact that I only played it around an hour of the game.This game when you first start it up starts to seems like it's one of those games that slips through the cracks and is a hidden gem. Though right after it started to try and teach me how to use some of your basic special abilities I was confused. As what it tells you to click and where to go doesn't always match up with what you need to do. So you just get a view of all of the massive amount of skills/abilites you can have, without having even any solid knowlage of how to use the basic skills. This doesn't even include the charcter creation section where you choose what three gene types you want to splice together with a vage idea of what atruibutes fit your play style. Then when the tutorial promp pops up to have you click the video for what it wants you to do. What it tells you to do isn't the same as what the video is called so you spend a few moments guessing and hopping you click the correct one.So, once you get past the tutorial and actually start to kill people it doesn't hold your hand on how to get to the objective. Which I actually liked, but there where so many options that it just kinda felt like none of them were fully fleshed out so to say. As if there were too many ideas just thrown together when ended up with something stand alone, but it's so much at once you don't know what you are doing or how some skills work. As well as feeling like everything was half finished before they added on new features and abilites. There is also the issue that it really likes to lag and glitch from time to time which happens much too frequently to be something that I can just ignore and keep playing. As it got to the point a few times that it just kept me from doing anything.Also, there are so many menus to go though that it feels more like it was made for a console/controler then a keyboard with the ability to lessen the amount of menus. By menus, I mean menus with in menus. Not just a lot of seperate menues.Over all, this is a really intresting game and you might like or even love it. Though you will really need to devote time to this game to figure out how everything works, but I couldn't as there were just too much meh feeling about it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												A very confusing yet fun cyberpunk shooter to play. Originally playing it back during release in 2011, it was a buggy mess full of broken translations and glitches that had further convoluted the game even worse than the present version. Over time, these issues were ironed out but the game still remains a very confusing yet enjoyable experience.This game is primary a FPS with character leveling, allowing your character to grow even stronger as you continue to play through the title. You start off as a rather weak soldier, but as both your character levels up and you gain more experience playing the game, you will end up as a cybernetic powerhouse able to take on entire groups of heavily armored enemies in both gratuitous flair and efficiency. Generally all the weapons here outside of a few are generally worth using, much like an RPG you'll unlock more weapons and equipment as you level up and earn more money.The story is both one of the greatest and worst things in this game. This game doesn't give you all the information outright and only gives small pieces every so often and the player is expected to piece all of this together over time. This can be a turnoff for some players used to more modern games that by the end of the playthrough, there is nothing new to learn or find out even in NG+. To the players that are patient enough to piece it all together, you do get a mostly intact yet shattered picture of the game, the factions and so on.The campaign of the game is one of the high points with this game for me. You can do the campaign both in singleplayer and in coop, and unlike what the game description says you can have up to 32 people in one campaign. It's a fairly short campaign in comparison to other games, but requires NG+++ in order to 100% the campaign. When you get a group of people together to play through the campaign, it's something magical that reminds me of playing a Serious Sam title in Co-Op mode. There are other multiplayer modes such as a CTF like mode with classes and a round based deathmatch mode for multiplayer, but the multiplayer for campaign is overall a more solid experience than these.In short, it's a fantastic yet confusing  FPS that is especially fun with friends. Typically it goes on sale anywhere from $1.00-$2.50 which is well worth it at this pricetag.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												There's not much that can out-cyberpunk a game in which you can hack the phantom memories of a dead person's brain and, should you fail, get counterhack-attacked by the ICE he had installed. Mind you, this wasn't in the story campaign, this was a randomly generated mission that popped up while I was messing around on one of the maps. The game makes no sense, is extremely user unfriendly, poorly translated, has a trial-and-error steep learning curve, most of the achievements are completely random and your legs are always broken. But I'll recommend it forever and always for the brouzouf.

												surprised i never wrote a review on this.you can do the entire campaign co-op.  only bad thing is only one player initiates\talks to the important NPC, all your co-op buddies can do is just tag along for the killing.  co-op with any server lan stuffs you can. 												Ever play a tabletop game of Shadowrun or Warhammer 40K and find yourself asking "Wouldn't this be awesome if I took some  LSD and played this as a video game?" The game has to be played to be believed as it is a very odd FPS/RPG Hybrid with an odd plot, strange characters, and all the anime-esque cyberpunk katana wielding hacker action you can stomach. It is the closest we've gotten to a modern equivilent to Deus Ex.

Posted: February 21, 2015
												Overview:   A great cyberpunk RPG. Don't expect to be able to follow the storyline without outside sources as all dialogue in the game is written in some language not yet seen to humankind and risen from the deepest pits of the nine hells. Also, some of it is in French and untranslated. The Storyline:    EYE's storyline is incomprehensible. None of it makes sense, and it isn't supposed to. There is an underlying storyline that is impossible to notice without venturing into the dark pits of the EYE forums that is only discernible if you manage to understand the dialogue which would require some form of extra-universal 10th dimensional being to assist you. The main storyline revolves around you, a futuristic Cyborg-Templar-Inquisitor. Your character is a member of a Templar-ish space wizard order who recently fractured and now theres also Ninja Space Wizards as well. You mainly fight against 'The Federation' a type of dystopian space government that has no real motives or beliefs behind their actions, and you're never told why you're attacking them. You also combat space-werewolf lizardmen xenomorphs called 'meta-streumonic creatures.'    Most of characters you meet are prone to excessive bouts of mood shifts and are generally mentally unstable. Also you have amnesia, and people get mad when you ask them about things your character should know, but that you donts because its never explained to you. Your character also has a wife, who is mentioned once, but never again, and is never seen. The final boss fight makes no sense and I have no idea why I was even fighting him. Also, there are Space-Jamaican Pirates on Mars.   At the beginning of the game you're told that some captain sent his wife into the forbidden place and she was executed as result. That captain was you. Then you went insane because you basically killed your wife. None of the events in the game actually happen, and your character is actually just living some kind of screwed up nightmare which kind of explains why nothing in the game makes any sense. 10 / 10 would recommendtl;dr  version:you gain brouzoufyou gain brouzoufmy legs are OKyou gain brouzouf

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												So, this is one of those it's a steam sale and it look interesting buys. As it was only a few dollars and it seemed like something new to play that I might start up every now and again for something new. Starting it up the graphics weren't anything to be thrilled with, but if it's a good game you don't have to have HD textrues. Plus, for a game type like this it's not really needed or the most important quality. Now I want to preface everything in this review with the simple fact that I only played it around an hour of the game.This game when you first start it up starts to seems like it's one of those games that slips through the cracks and is a hidden gem. Though right after it started to try and teach me how to use some of your basic special abilities I was confused. As what it tells you to click and where to go doesn't always match up with what you need to do. So you just get a view of all of the massive amount of skills/abilites you can have, without having even any solid knowlage of how to use the basic skills. This doesn't even include the charcter creation section where you choose what three gene types you want to splice together with a vage idea of what atruibutes fit your play style. Then when the tutorial promp pops up to have you click the video for what it wants you to do. What it tells you to do isn't the same as what the video is called so you spend a few moments guessing and hopping you click the correct one.So, once you get past the tutorial and actually start to kill people it doesn't hold your hand on how to get to the objective. Which I actually liked, but there where so many options that it just kinda felt like none of them were fully fleshed out so to say. As if there were too many ideas just thrown together when ended up with something stand alone, but it's so much at once you don't know what you are doing or how some skills work. As well as feeling like everything was half finished before they added on new features and abilites. There is also the issue that it really likes to lag and glitch from time to time which happens much too frequently to be something that I can just ignore and keep playing. As it got to the point a few times that it just kept me from doing anything.Also, there are so many menus to go though that it feels more like it was made for a console/controler then a keyboard with the ability to lessen the amount of menus. By menus, I mean menus with in menus. Not just a lot of seperate menues.Over all, this is a really intresting game and you might like or even love it. Though you will really need to devote time to this game to figure out how everything works, but I couldn't as there were just too much meh feeling about it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to play a gun-toting, sword-wielding, cyborg knight with the force caught up in a corporate war?EYE is not for everyone, but if you've ever wondered what it would be like if in-depth Morrowind-style RPG mechanics got mixed up with Half-Life 2's FPS mechanics, and the whole mix were turned up to eleven, buy this game.In one mission I got overwhelmed by monsters and my character snapped under the pressure. I had to run like a sissy while my character fired his weapon uncontrollably at shadows and hallucinated explosions.In another, I accidentally got caught in crossfire between some allies and the enemy forces, and my character freaked out and hallucinated that my allies were the bad guys.I tried to hack a security console and it hacked me back.I overused my psionic powers and my head exploded.---This game does have issues. If you like to have allies (this game lets you conjure them with sci fi magic), you'll find they get in the way quite often, especially in cramped areas. If you head back into an area outside of that area's mission, you'll find that enemies are set to respawn very frequently, which is not everyone's cup of tea. You can tweak the AI settings and respawn rates in the options menu, but not quite enough for some areas. As many people mention, the English translation in this game is poor, but there's a community-made patch that fixes most of that. Sound quality can be hit and miss, but on the whole the gunplay sounds satisfying. Sadly there is very little voice acting in this game! The bulk of all interaction you'll have with NPCs is done through text.---If you're willing to deal with that and you want a game with excellent gunplay, hardcore RPG mechanics, and inventory management, that overwhelms you with options and makes absolutely no apologies for its learning curve and occasionally brutal difficulty, pick this game up. If you're unsure whether this is your cup of tea, I encourage you to at least watch a Let's Play and check out the demo. This game will definitely be sucking up a lot of my time.6/10 without community grammar patch, 8/10 with.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Where to start? I don't want to say that this game is terrible, but...it's awful. Don't get me wrong, there are a LOT of really good concepts in this game. Head trauma, limb wounds (though some of those seem to be thrown around at random with no real cause) bleeding out from wounds. The cybertech is all fairly cool, but that seems to more or less only apply to long-running multiplayer servers or single player, though to be honest, ♥♥♥♥ if I could tell what was going on half the time because of the horrible, rampant Engrish. The single player campaign seems like an afterthought, cooked up by a sweatshop worker on his breaks between contemplating his lack of shoes and staring at those steam pipes.One of the good points of the game, however, is that you have the absolute freedom to attack and kill anything. And I mean ANYTHING. Enemy? Sweet. Helpless animal? Go right ahead. Non-essential NPC? Blow him away! Essential NPC? NOBODY IS SAFE! However, the poorly designed interface makes it so hard to tell friend from foe that I spent half of the time running from my friends popping cyberclonespell or whatever it was and trying to find the next armory. The Armory system is by far one of the best systems in the game, combining inventory tetris from Diablo and the carry weight from Fallout. Good game? No. Good B-game? Ooooh yeah.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												So I hear that some people don't like this game, but I don't really understand why. Most likely they're expecting it to be a different type of game, but it's basically an RPG style mod for an FPS game. That's what it is and what it's supposed to be. In my opinion it's pretty successful at this.The main problems with the game are relatively minor, like the font size is too small for modern displays and there's no way to increase it. There are some other minor UI type issues that basicaly seem to stem from the fact that it's an FPS engine mod being sold as a game, and from the fact that the game is a bit dated.The art style in the game is great though. It's basically a combo between the Necromongers from the Riddick movies and the usual cybrpunk stuff (hacking, implants, etc.) The overall level design isn't amazing but it isn't too bad. (It sort of looks like maybe someone designed the levels without too much regard to what quests would be in those levels or how they'd work, then the quest/mission content was added later.) So the levels don't naturally lead you toward quest objectives, but this could be good or bad depening on whether you want your hand held or you want a more realistic experience. (Quest markers exist, but they don't necessarily lead you easily to a waypoint because the actual path you need to take to get there may be kind of convoluted. However there is a "spell" that does pathfinding toward the next quest marker.)In short, it's a unique RPG FPS game with a few rough edges in the UI, and it's kind of dated at this point, but it's cetainly worth picking up especially on sale. If you want CS:GO don't buy it, but if you want a uniqe FPS RPG with a cyberpunk psionic necromonger type theme and don't mind that its an older game then do buy it especially since it's inexpensive.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												THIS IS THE CRAZIEST SOURCEMOD EVER CREATED IN THE HISTORY OF MAN.Install the improved translation mod before you do anything -at all- with this game. Play as a rambo character and become overpowered first before specializing in hacking or psi powers.If games were like alcohol, EYE is like a terrible-tasting and mysterious throat-burning whiskey that also makes you hallucinate and you have no idea what is even happening, but it is awful and amazing at the same time. The balance of the game is absolutely horrendous. Stealth, hacking and psionic builds will be hard-pressed to gain any experience, money or leverage at all; If you are not a ghost-in-the-shell holocaust murder agent you are the equivalent of someone with an english major.The only way to make money or gain experience efficiently is to kill hundreds and hundreds of enemies or speedrun side missions, which could take up to an hour. The maps are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly huge and are designed to be labyrinths. The maps are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥LY XBOX HUGE. It takes maybe 5 minutes to run from point A to point B, where dozens of high-level enemies constantly spawn close to you and make it impossible to catch a break or to heal yourself. Always upgrade your cyber legs.The AI is actually kind of smart and very vicious; they will throw grenades, rush you, corner you and flank you for any chance they get; when there is a 6-story tall cyberdemon only inches between you and a foot soldier, you are still enemy number one. If you dislike constant long-range combat, modify it such that enemies will only notice you at shorter distances and you'll have an easier time with both stealth and gunplay.Besides all of that, this game has an overwhelmingly chaotic atmosphere, very well-done dystopian aesthetics, and swarms upon swarms of enemies that present a constant threat and danger throughout the game. The developers crammed so many elements into the game that an invisible rambo super-fast armored gunslinging cyborg ninja who hacks into people's brains, uses psionic powers and jumps 6 feet into the air is UNDERPOWERED.Cons: Bad translation, incomprehensible to the layman, horrible balance, STUPIDLY GIGANTIC XBOX HUGE MAPS (I cannot stress this enough), no tutorials, a few bullet sponge enemies and a punishing autosave system.Pros: It will all be worth it if you want your head to explode from all of the chaos. I still have PTSD from the Mars mission. This game leaves me wordless to say what really went on in my mind when every element culminated into blasting down helicopters and cyberdemons the size of grand canyons left and right.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												TL;DR:A mashup of Warhammer 40k, Shadowrun, and Deus Ex. The ingredients are right for a perfectly cooked masterpiece, but you have to eat it with chop sticks. Hard at first, but fun once you get the hang of it. Also now a days when it goes on sale it's now only $1, so you can't go wrong.Pre-face:Right now before I get into the meat of this, this game currently has a horrible tutorial for its mechanics and was impossible for me to get into the first time I picked it up, but...Interesting Tidbits:From last I heard the development house has gone through some rough patches. With people up and disapearing from work, and certain complications. Right now the game can be seen as incomplete, but it is a hidden gem of a game.Pros:(+++) Point for point customization (Inventory Tetris, Augmentations, Psionic Powers, Hacking, Cybermancy)(+++) Nitty gritty cyberpunk done right(++) Multiple paths to victory in a given objective(+) You can have special eyes(+) On sale it goes for almost nothing(+?) Tons of complexity (Note, the complexity is the currency with which you buy depth)Cons:(---) No true ending(---) Terrible explination of how the game works (I'm looking at you research)(---) game crippling mistakes that can ruin playthroughs (Dying with low Karma can incure persistent debuffs to stats without expensive research)(--) No more then 3 weapons of a given class(--) Enemy AI is lack luster at times(-) The game is sadly as is. The chance of a update is almost non-existent.Tips:WIKI WIKI WIKI, people have made your life easy. Don't be afraid to make mistakes at first, we all restarted at some point to remake our characters.The heavy sniper can shoot through walls, have fun.Conclusion:A experience akin to the original Deus Ex, little to no handholding. Character customization closer to pen and paper table top games. Play any character you can think of in this world. Sadly despite all these things, I can ignore the obvious faults. Not as bad as the hundreds of pages I had to read in Dungeons and Dragons, but a hefty time investment. If you are iffy on this title wait for a sale to take it down to a couple of dollars, and give it a spin.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												How would one describe this game to a gamer unaware of it's existence and is looking for something new and is interested in what your have to say about it. Well, luckily you now know about this game seeing as how you maybe reading this review so that's a plus. So I'm going to write a review based off the idea the person reading it hasn't seen any trailers or gameplay videos, and hasn't had the story or world explained to them.This game lookes better then most that came out that same year. For an Indie title that's impressive. As for the gameplay... it's unique yet familiar. You have your FPS/RPG style game. You jump, crouch, shoot, aim down the sights, you have an inventory with VERY limited space so there's no bottomless pockets on your armor, you get to choose your loadout from a very good number of possibilites. You can mix up have one sword or three, dual-weilding both swords and pistols, you can have submachine gunes, assault rifles, sniper rifles, shotguns, a minigun, and a sword that makes people explode when you hit them with it. Grenades, med kits, and at some point you can purchase turrets. I found the "speed malus" intriguing. Instead of just having limited space (which you do) how much you carry on you and the weight of each individual item will slow your base movement speed. This also applies to the three different armor types you can have (light, medium, heavy). You also get powers in this game. The story takes place in the future. I don't know how far but it's pretty damn far in my opinion. And your a part of a cult of cyborg wizards... I'm serious. OKay more accurately a secret organization that deals with weird things that are created from your worst nightmares and brought to a physical form in our realm. There's also civil issues with a government group and a rival "cult" apart of the same organization as you. But that's all I'm going to give away. Back to the powers. You can create clones, of which you can slaughter at your behest but becareful cuase you can lose mental stats which do actually effect you in this game. You don't want to be some cyborg wizard with no sanity to speak of do you? Anyway, you can teleport to an enemies position making them explode into pieces and your end up taking there spot in line at the local alien MCDonalds. There's tech abilities as well as your weird magic abilities like the ones I just described. You can cloak, sprint faster and jump higher (similar to the Crysis game but you get faster and jump higher as your stats increase as well so eventually you'll be jumping around like Alex Mercer, or the Hulk for those of you who don't know about the game Prototype) you can get a special vision that helps you target enemies and see anybody who might be cloaked, and you can perform maintanence on yourself if you get message saying you've got a broken leg or something. I told you that you were a cyborg wizard.Anyway one of the things I find most interesting about this game is the research aspect and the upgrades to your body that you can make. Now there was a reviewer who said not to expect Deus Ex and quite frankly other then this part I'm about to explain I don't know why you would, Deus Ex was about the controversy and challenges of living in a world where you could enhance your body and become part machine where E.Y.E is about... well I'm still not entire sure I haven't gotten that far yet. SO! There are objects you find while traveling that help you research for new alloys and upgrades, although I will admit it's been awhile since I've played and even then I didn't fully understand how it worked but I know that researching is necessary. IT's cool to because it'll give you a time of how long it'll take to complete the research how you can speed it up by spending money on the research. Now the part that is somewhat similar to Deus Ex is that you can upgrade individual parts of your cyborg wizard to improve his performance. For example, putting funds into upgrading your eyes will help your accuarcy and reduce the effects of flash bangs and other such quirks. Upgrading your legs again makes your run faster and jump higher. Improving your body will make you take less damage and you can upgrade your brain so your better at hacking. Yes you can also hack just about anything in this game. Enemies and there turrets, security systems, doors, you name it. The hacking aspect is like a fast paced mini-startegy game.I can't possibly explain everything in this review nor do I want to but that is a lot of the aspects of the game in what four paragraphs? Anyway I recommend this game it's fairly enjoyable and it doesn't hold your hand. Oh and I almost forgot to mention enemies will send reinforcements to an area so standing around isn't a good idea. Also, another fun fact is you can change the difficulty of the game and the rate at which enemy reinforcements arrive to the area your in. Anyway have fun.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is a game that can easily be described as a poor man's Deus Ex. It's short, it's dumb, it's hard to follow, and it looks ok at best. But there's a massive degree of freedom that this game just throws at you right off the back and an incredibly deep level of complexity to the way you kit out your character with guns, cybernetic upgrades, skills, and even spells that not even Human Revolution was able to pull off, and I'm not even exaggerating about this. It may seem confusing at first and it's a lot to take in a first but it all meshes together so well it even impressed Jim Sterling himself.It's dumb, but it's a lot of unbridled fun. It's crazy dumb fun all over the place and it's cheaper now than it was at launch you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												The graphics are immersive somehow even with the 4x4 texture limit generously given by the Source engine.  The storyline is decent, though it's very hard to understand.  The ranged weapons feel good, melee feels meaty, and hacking is partly dynamic on how good you are rather than your stats, which is something I appreciate.If you have high expectations, don't bother.  This game has many flaws (none of which are gamebreaking), but the concepts are well thought out, if a bit lacking on execution.The menu is strange at best and there's so many things that I don't even understand, but the research system is neat.  You can also augment yourself very much in a Deus Ex style to boost your abilities.If you've played Deus Ex or games like it: Yes.If you can enjoy a game with minor flaws: Yes.If you use a controller: No.If you have high expectations: No.If you're just reading reviews: Play the demo, it'll give you a much better idea of what you're buying.

Play as a rambo character and become overpowered first before specializing in hacking or psi powers.If games were like alcohol, EYE is like a terrible-tasting and mysterious throat-burning whiskey that also makes you hallucinate and you have no idea what is even happening, but it is awful and amazing at the same time. The balance of the game is absolutely horrendous. Stealth, hacking and psionic builds will be hard-pressed to gain any experience, money or leverage at all; If you are not a ghost-in-the-shell holocaust murder agent you are the equivalent of someone with an english major.The only way to make money or gain experience efficiently is to kill hundreds and hundreds of enemies or speedrun side missions, which could take up to an hour. The maps are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly huge and are designed to be labyrinths. The maps are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥LY XBOX HUGE. It takes maybe 5 minutes to run from point A to point B, where dozens of high-level enemies constantly spawn close to you and make it impossible to catch a break or to heal yourself. Always upgrade your cyber legs.The AI is actually kind of smart and very vicious; they will throw grenades, rush you, corner you and flank you for any chance they get; when there is a 6-story tall cyberdemon only inches between you and a foot soldier, you are still enemy number one. If you dislike constant long-range combat, modify it such that enemies will only notice you at shorter distances and you'll have an easier time with both stealth and gunplay.Besides all of that, this game has an overwhelmingly chaotic atmosphere, very well-done dystopian aesthetics, and swarms upon swarms of enemies that present a constant threat and danger throughout the game. The developers crammed so many elements into the game that an invisible rambo super-fast armored gunslinging cyborg ninja who hacks into people's brains, uses psionic powers and jumps 6 feet into the air is UNDERPOWERED.Cons: Bad translation, incomprehensible to the layman, horrible balance, STUPIDLY GIGANTIC XBOX HUGE MAPS (I cannot stress this enough), no tutorials, a few bullet sponge enemies and a punishing autosave system.Pros: It will all be worth it if you want your head to explode from all of the chaos. I still have PTSD from the Mars mission. This game leaves me wordless to say what really went on in my mind when every element culminated into blasting down helicopters and cyberdemons the size of grand canyons left and right.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												The graphics are immersive somehow even with the 4x4 texture limit generously given by the Source engine.  The storyline is decent, though it's very hard to understand.  The ranged weapons feel good, melee feels meaty, and hacking is partly dynamic on how good you are rather than your stats, which is something I appreciate.If you have high expectations, don't bother.  This game has many flaws (none of which are gamebreaking), but the concepts are well thought out, if a bit lacking on execution.The menu is strange at best and there's so many things that I don't even understand, but the research system is neat.  You can also augment yourself very much in a Deus Ex style to boost your abilities.If you've played Deus Ex or games like it: Yes.If you can enjoy a game with minor flaws: Yes.If you use a controller: No.If you have high expectations: No.If you're just reading reviews: Play the demo, it'll give you a much better idea of what you're buying.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												TL;DR:A mashup of Warhammer 40k, Shadowrun, and Deus Ex. The ingredients are right for a perfectly cooked masterpiece, but you have to eat it with chop sticks. Hard at first, but fun once you get the hang of it. Also now a days when it goes on sale it's now only $1, so you can't go wrong.Pre-face:Right now before I get into the meat of this, this game currently has a horrible tutorial for its mechanics and was impossible for me to get into the first time I picked it up, but...Interesting Tidbits:From last I heard the development house has gone through some rough patches. With people up and disapearing from work, and certain complications. Right now the game can be seen as incomplete, but it is a hidden gem of a game.Pros:(+++) Point for point customization (Inventory Tetris, Augmentations, Psionic Powers, Hacking, Cybermancy)(+++) Nitty gritty cyberpunk done right(++) Multiple paths to victory in a given objective(+) You can have special eyes(+) On sale it goes for almost nothing(+?) Tons of complexity (Note, the complexity is the currency with which you buy depth)Cons:(---) No true ending(---) Terrible explination of how the game works (I'm looking at you research)(---) game crippling mistakes that can ruin playthroughs (Dying with low Karma can incure persistent debuffs to stats without expensive research)(--) No more then 3 weapons of a given class(--) Enemy AI is lack luster at times(-) The game is sadly as is. The chance of a update is almost non-existent.Tips:WIKI WIKI WIKI, people have made your life easy. Don't be afraid to make mistakes at first, we all restarted at some point to remake our characters.The heavy sniper can shoot through walls, have fun.Conclusion:A experience akin to the original Deus Ex, little to no handholding. Character customization closer to pen and paper table top games. Play any character you can think of in this world. Sadly despite all these things, I can ignore the obvious faults. Not as bad as the hundreds of pages I had to read in Dungeons and Dragons, but a hefty time investment. If you are iffy on this title wait for a sale to take it down to a couple of dollars, and give it a spin.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												It's an atmospheric FPS RPG in which you go through missions being a badass augmented ninja, completing objectives, and taking out enemies with an array of weapons, such as pistols, machine guns, shotguns, sniper rifles, or my favorite; melee weapons. How about a sword that explodes enemies on contact eh?You can buy stuff from the store with money gained from killing enemies, etc, and research misc items that enemies can drop, which can unlock abilities or improve existing attributes of your character.Hacking is also an element in the game, you can do things like hack a door open, turn a turret to your side, or even hack an ATM! But if you lose a hacking minigame, you will get hacked yourself. When that happens you get quite an annoying overlay on your screen saying HACKED!, and cannot hack anything else unless it either goes away on its own, or you hack yourself to get rid of it. You can even lose a hacking battle against yourself! HACKCEPTION!It can get frustrating at times, but for the most part its pretty fun, also its a great value for 10 dollars.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												EYE: Divine Cybermancy is what happens when Deus Ex takes up Warhammer 40,000 as a hobby. A brilliantly atmospheric and characterful game, EYE's world is not fine and dandy. From offering to relieve potential business partners of their heads to encouraging a man to commit suicide, you play with the lock on the door between mean and downright vindictive. Of course, the rest of the world is waiting for you to open the door; spirit werewolves, federal soldiers, bandits and giant cyberdemons are amongst the various enemies you can face in this game.You can use a number of means to go about this game; from straight up rifle combat, heavy weapons use and melee to stealthed sniping, hacking and psychic prowess, there is no singled out method by which one can complete missions. A particular air of revelation is about EYE, making it one of the most enjoyable FPS games I've ever played.The worst thing that could be said about this game is that the translation from French isn't always coherent. Some of the menus are less than intuitive and there isn't a lot of help moving between interfaces. However, personally I reckon the slightly broken English adds something unfamiliar enough to the game to make it feel more alien a world.

												This game is interesting from a design standpoint, if not nescessarily terribly good. It has an incredibly complex character system and allows you a huge number of different approaches to completing its missions, then sabotages itself by making simply mowing everything down with a chaingun by far the easiest method of getting by. This game is often confusing and tries to tell a story that is hard to follow.Worth a look if you're into games that have unique mechanics and settings, but not worth buying if you're looking for something that comes without major frustrations and shortcomings.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Recommended but only just.The Good:The story is certainly interestingThe settings are also interestingCyber Ninja powers (!)Certain sections look very nice indeedThe Meh:The controls are funky and rebinding them is almost mandatoryThe graphics in the majority of places are atrocious for a 2011 release and could easily be from 2003The gun and sword play is decidely averageThe Bad:The ******* translation. To say it is bad would be an understantment. For a story as conveluted as E.Y.E.'s you have to be able to read the text with minimal difficulty. I believe the studio is French but that is no excuse. England is only 30 minutes away!The world is empty. Oh, sure, there are monsters and bad guys aplenty but there is no one else around at all. It feels extremely lifeless and isolating.The AI is below average. If you are not behind something. or cloaked, the enemy will magically turn on the spot and come straight for you with guns blazing.Infinitely spawning enemies. 'Nuff said.Conclusion:With the current trend of remaking everything, from classic games to film franchises, E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy would be a prime target for such treatment. Updated graphics, AI, translation etc could easily put this game in contention for GotY.I may have listed quiet a few negatives there, and they can be extremely aggrevating,  but, for those willing to push on through, you can find the sparks of a great game and I do recommend giving it a fair shot.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Straight to it: the save function is quirkly designed and unexpected. The gameplay itself is rather clunky, too. I've no interest in playing a RPG that doesn't allow me to save my progress whenever I want, or that has checkpoint saves so far apart that it literally would take hours to reach each one if you chose to opt for sidequests. For that matter, I've little time to play anything built on the Source engine. It's decrepit; the graphics feel like late '90's, and player interactions with the environment feel decidedly antiquated.  Finally, why is the game so dark? It's really freaking dark! In the same vein as Doom 3.TL;DR: Bad save system by design and old engine leaves this one for the hardcore nerds who have LOTS of time to blow off.

number of helpful: 19 of 39 people (49%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												edit: if you think I've totally missed the point, then please comment and tell me what I've missed! I really want to like this game, but I think it misses the mark.Original:I haven't got the remotest ****ing clue what is going on in this game. And not in a clever, mysterious, well-crafted-world-where-not-all-is-as-it-seems way, which it's clear the devs were trying for. Even overlooking the english-as-a-second-language mistakes, the writing is utter garbage. Too many factions and characters introduced too quickly and making no apparent difference to what's going on.I have amnesia and don't know anything about my situation, yet I have opinions and memories about various characters?More importantly, I don't understand the gameplay mechanics and there's very little explanation. You need to remember the briefing dialogue, because despite there being a high tech character UI it doesn't record dialogue and the objectives it does record don't give you any idea why you're doing them if you don't remember the details.This game is a mess. It wants very badly to be a blend of Syndicate, Deus Ex, and possibly Fallout's Brotherhood of Steel. It doesn't succeed. There's probably a good game somewhere in there, but there's so much mess that should have been stripped out or implemented better.Not explaining anything in game is not a substitute for cleverness. It's just an inscrutable, badly put together mess.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												As others have said, it's near impossible to know what is going on due to bad translations and seemingly a lack of good organization, therefore it is difficult to maintain interest in the plot...whatever that is. The dialogue reads like a child whose second language is English wrote it; overly simple and full of mistakes. This GREATLY affects immersion. Immersion is kind of important in a story-driven/RPG game.Speaking of the dialogue, it's text-based and a ton of reading. If I wanted to read a badly written story, I'd pick up a book by whoever wrote 'Twilight'. Despite that, the premise is good from what I read on the store page; it may not have been half as bad if the translation were better and the dialogue less childlike.The graphics are good but devoid of anything interesting or much that's interactive, there is a lot of empty space to trudge through.UI and UX are an absolute mess. If you want to play with a controller, forget about it. You won't be able to access most anything via controller besides cycling through weapons, using the weapons, and pausing the game. Though you can control movement with a controller... Everything else (picking things up, hacking, dialogue, accessing UI, etc.) must be done with the keyboard, so it's simpler to stick with the keyboard/mouse combo throughout. I feel there is way too much going on with the various menus, it was not intuitive whatsoever and took too long for me to grow accustomed to.0/10 -- I found no redeeming qualities, even the low price I paid. In an RPG I want to INTERACT, be a PART of and guide the story. None of those things were possible for me here. I don't hate this game, I simply find nothing to recommend it.1/11: edited to include more info re: gamepad vs. keyboard/mouse

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2012
												A surfeit of good ideas undone by♥♥♥♥♥♥poor execution.  I can't think of another game which is, by turns, as awesome and awful as E.Y.E.  It creates a great first impression, however, with one of the biggest and (seemingly) complex stat and upgrade systems of any action RPG out there, with lots of different unique powers to buy (invisibility cloaks, the ability to clone yourself and control enemies with your mind, etc, etc) and scores of different weapons (most of which handle pretty well).Unfortunately, all of these good ideas can't do much to counter the game's terrible A.I., boring combat, constantly respawning enemies, erratic level design (some are well done, while others are just big empty boxes), and incomprehensible writing/storyline.  So at the end of the day the game's RPG pretensions are for naught: no matter how many upgrades you buy or how many times you level up the game still plays like an amateurish, unfinished, sub-mediocre Half-Life 2 mod.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Warning: This Game is not Controller Friendly.This may not be an issue for a lot of people, but it was an absolute deal breaker for me.  Normally, when a game is listed as having Partial Controller Support, it is mostly playable with your controller and only occasionally requires you to use your mouse or keyboard.  This is simply not the case with this game.  There are far too many required functions to be able to map them all to a standard controller, so you will need to use your keyboard so much that even attempting to use the controller just seems pointless.Again, I realize that this isn't  an issue for a lot of PC gamers, but I feel like those who, like me, prefer to play their games wilth a controller will be disappointed with just how hard it is to play this game with one.  It's too bad; this one looks like it could have been a fun cyberpunk adventure.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This game has a lot of interesting ideas, but they are poorly integrated into a clunky, unintuitive and ultimately disappointing mess. Like hacking? Even with loads of point in hacking everything but doors take way too long. The respawning enemies patrolling around the level will spot and unload into you before you can hope to finish. Regular things are a chore to hack. Even with 50 points in hacking I had trouble opening a ventilation shaft in a later level, necessitating several runs of spamming the shield and attack options for minutes on end.Like blowing things up with your mind? EYE fares much better here, but the stat requirements for the most powerful psi-spells meant that after wasting many points on hacking I had to resort to heavy grinding to be able to use them before the end of the campaign. By the way, dont even bother with the methods listed in the grinding guides on the community hub, a custom map "cm_farm_alpha23" will get you your brouzoufs/xp much, much faster, without the infuriating and frequent stat penalties incurred from falling down a hole on the Minos map.Cybernetic implants will be familiar to any Deus Ex player and do what they need to, however if you wish to use several of them as well as psi powers your quick actions menu will be overloaded, and the psi-power selector is far too cumbersome when you are switching between over five powers in the heat of combat. The clunkiness of the controls is made worse by the actions menu leaving the flow of game time at its normal pace, and that weapons are assigned hotkeys based on the order you last added them to your inventory, leaving you stumbling to find your medkit when you have a sliver of health left. Deus Ex easily had a far better system of weapon/skill hotkeys, 11 years before EYE was released.Everything is poorly explained. Game is listed as having co-op, but it only works if you and a friend are willing to jump through many hoops. Dialog sucks, bad english and criminal surfer gangs abound. Many dialog trees have half the options end the conversation and initiate combat, while redundant the hostile option switch in the order of responses, seemingly to punish people skipping through text. Weapons all seem pretty fun but prepare to grind if you want to use the biggest and baddest ones within your first campaign. Enemy and ally AI is abysmal, humans will stop the exact spot they see you and fire their semiautomatic weapons without end. Mutant enemies will run into your bullets single file. Levels are apparently designed to have you drain all your energy sprinting around. If you come to this game with low expectations and dont bother with hacking, it might be worth buying at 90% off. Otherwise stay clear of it.4/10

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												So much is wrong with this game that I can't recommend it. Not for ten dollars, and not to anyone but the biggest cyberpunk fans. There are just so many common sense things missing and so many awful design choices that I cannot recommend it, not even for a dollar. It's a shame because the game is ALMOST good. The only thing keeping it from being good is the sheer number of things wrong with it.Things it does right:- A somewhat interesting story that I won't spoil here.- The story has choices that slightly alter little things later on in the game, and they are EVERYWHERE, even if the spelling and grammar leaves a bit to be desired.- There are multiple endings. The game is designed to be replayed over again multiple times to get all of the endings.- Graphics and art direction are top shelf stuff, for a Source game.- Soundtrack is great, I really enjoyed it.- The weapons look and feel good, and the gear is generally pretty useful (turrets, for example, which you can place up to 8 in a game).- MOST (not all) of the cybernetic upgrades really do make you feel more powerful as you upgrade them.- Lots of cyberpunk references, which is great if you like cyberpunk.And now to list all of the problems this game has (that I can think of):- Absolutely horrid multiplayer component that requires you to forward your ports and then jump through a specific set of hoops in order for your friends to be able to join your game every time you start a server. Your friends also have to have their ports forwarded to be able to join. This is unacceptable for a game in 2011, let alone any time after that. The devs have decided, however, that this is perfectly fine and have made no attempts to update the game in order to make online play work smoothly.-♥♥♥♥♥♥poor admin controls. By default, you're only able to use the addid command to temporarily ban a player from your game. The ban only lasts for the duration that the server stays up, and doesn't seem to add the player to the banned players list. The banned player will not be told they are banned, and upon trying to reconnect will just get instantly disconnected. There's no excuse for this, especially considering that the Source engine, by default, allows you to have a list of banned players by SteamID, and actively adds banned players to the list as you ban them. Why was this removed or altered in any way? Even if there is a way to ban players using third party tools, this is unacceptable.- While we're on the subject of console commands, this game lacks them. You can't cheat, most of the commands you enter will give you a "HURR STOP CHEATING" warning. This means you can't even noclip if you get stuck somewhere, let alone any of the other fun or useful stuff that you can do with console commands.- The levels all seem to have been poorly playtested, as there are areas where enemies can go right through solid walls and shoot out at you.- Awful enemy spawning system, which ties into the statement above about the game being poorly playtested. There will be spawn areas where enemies will start to spawn practically right in front of you if you turn the camera away just enough. This happens in almost every level in the game, and there are some levels that are especially bad for it.- Number of enemies and how often they spawn is very inconsistent from level to level. The devs added options to change spawn frequency at some point, which helped, but not much. Some levels will have an overwhelming number of enemies pouring in at you, while others, with the exact same spawn settings, will pretty much be a drought. Again, this seems to be a problem stemming from lack of playtesting.- Dropships with rockets are contrastingly powerful when compared to almost all of the other enemies in the game. They can catch you off guard (read: SPAWN RIGHT ABOVE OR BEHIND YOU) and blast you to bits in less than three seconds flat. This is especially troubling in some levels that have poor visibility. They can see you but you can't see them. Better yet, there are certain areas where they can somehow go right through a wall and then shoot at you back through said wall.- Tons of grammar and spelling errors.- A weird little glitch in the inventory system where your ammo count will not match up with what's actually in your inventory.- An asinine and pointless karma system, which is attached to a system that gives you semi-permanent stat penalties if you die while you have low karma.- A leveling system that can be abused by way of gaining semi-permanent stat penalties from killing yourself or dying. Once a stat starts requiring more than one point in order to increase its level, just get a semi-permanent stat penalty so that you only have to pay one point. Once you're satisfied, research the items necessary to remove these semi-permanent stat penalties, and there you go, you spent significantly less points than you otherwise would have on your stats.- The game is hard for new players to understand, and can be very alienating for new players- Whatever is left of the multiplayer community is comprised of tryhard fantards of the game. They'll try to order new players around, aren't very helpful, and generally act like elitist♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ This is awful to have to deal with when one of them joins your game while you're playing with friends and decides to start acting disruptive. When you ban someone, you also have to kick them in order for it to work, and they won't be permanently banned. Kicking someone restarts the level. This is a huge problem, and also probably the main reason you don't see many servers up. People who want to play co-op will play it privately with their friends in order to avoid dealing with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who wanna ruin their easily ruinable fun.Overall a 4/10, maybe 5/10 on a good day. Get it on sale for a dollar if you like cyberpunk and don't mind putting up with a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t in your games, otherwise avoid at any price.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												Terrible game with terrible keybinds, just a mess! All I wanted was to get some cards to the steam winter thingy, and I went to play it... Geez, the problem starts in the creating of your character! You don`t know who you are, You don`t know what you are and you have to choose betwen some weird combination of things that you don`t know what are you doing! You finish randomly choosing whatever and going in... Then part of the tutorial is like any other games: Letters pop out and you know what to do, then some "press enter to pick up the pistol" appeared and... guess what... The action button is the enter. Yep. Then, the tutorial tells me to press T to watch tutorial videos????? Really??? Nope, pressed up any button and I could pass through that part. I had a pistol and a katana. found some enemies, went to kill them with my pistol and i had no precision at all, even in the sights, pulled out my katana and the enemies start to throw grenades at me? Wow, that scalated quickly. Passed through that too. Finally, Some strange door is in my way, with "hack" on it. 5 minutes to figure how to hack that damn door and guess what, the door hacked me and killed me. At that point, I alt tabbed the game, got the cards and damn, uninstalled that ♥♥♥♥♥, because that's what you do with this game.

content:
Posted: March 20
												Ever imagined what a game would look like if you combined Half-Life 2, Deus Ex and Warhammer and put it in a steampunkish world? Sounds great? Yeah, it would. But now remove everything that's awesome and you get this pile of nonsense.I really tried to like this game. It has some great ideas, but it all gets butchered away by those massive flaws.Pros:- The weapon design is pretty good.- The handling of the weapons when hitting enemies was decent.- Fighting was very tight and actually really fun!- Overall graphics, there was nothing to complain about.- The design of the characters was very refreshing. Seeing how the Inquisition could look in 200 hundred years? OH YES!Cons:- The first level / dream sequence. To introduce a gamer properly to a game, what would be the best way? Ah yes, of course, the worst level the gaming industry has to offer. What could go possible go wrong?- The ingame currency is called Brouzouf. Well, did they just took a dictionary and looked for the worst-sounding word they could find? Surely they did, and succeeded.- The ingame menu. Ho. Ly. Hell. Is it even possible to make it even more complicated and frustrating to use? I don't think so.- The story. What the hell is even happening? It was very hard to focus and follow anything.- There is some kind of helping section / FAQ within the game, but it's so useless you're more confused after reading it than before. It just states "Look for the Hacking entry in the help section." Why can't the game itself put up a dialog or window to show me how to do it?- Having PSI powers and such is a great idea, but I don't had the feeling they helped much.- The levels are great in general design, but ridiculously gigantic. You're feeling like an escaping lab rat. Ever played Serious Sam? Well against this game, Serious Sam has tiny levels. Other problem is, they are extremely dull and there is almost nothing to exlore; only dead ends that lead absolutey nowhere, only one door that you can open and so on. Here and there are NPC with a mission for you, but these sections are so offside it almost feels like a different level.- Enemies are sharpshooters. No matter what weapon they have, they will hit you at ANY distance with the accuracy of a sniper. Most of the time you're being hit and you have absolutely no idea from where.- Once your enemies see you, they'll hunt you and they know exactly where you are.- Respawning enemies. Because ♥♥♥♥ you, player!- The inventory is horrendous to use. I constantly picked up ammo and was also constantly running out of ammo of the same type. What the hell. Reordering is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥and you have to drag and drop the ammo clip in the exact corner of the cell of your inventory or it doesn't work. Guess the developers had never ever ever ever played this game by themselves.- The hacking system? I don't have a clue, this has to be the biggest, most imbecil implementation of any hacking system ever invented. And the so called tutorial is an even bigger joke.- Voice acting is terrible. It sounds like the same voice actor was first punshed in the throat, then chained in a huge tin and forced to read all those lines.So, I really can't recommend this game. It has some great ideas in a postapocalyptic steampunkish world, but the interface, the enemies, the huge levels... everything is a huge disappointment and letdown.

												This game, this game right here is literally cancer on screen. It's fun and kind of challenging and all around a pleaserable experience for you and up to 3 friends. Then you reach Mars, and I swear to god this level will make friends into enemies and enemies into dead people. You're contantly barraged with tanks, gun ships and tanky♥♥♥♥♥dudes with rocket launchers that can snipe you from around the world. The level in completely brown and has no markers on where you're supposed to go and is the size of Africa. All around that level ruins the game. I'd recommend this game if, and only if, you know someone that you'd rather not know or be friends with. When this game goes on sale buy a copy for you and said person. Play through it with them and when you get to this level, true feelings will flow freely and you're hatred will pour forth. That person will never want to speak to you again. I know from personal experience 10/10

content:
Posted: January 3
												I want this game to be so much better than it is... It is frustrating when you die and end up 4 missions back from when you died, especially when the thing that killed you gave no warning (not even a sound, just a red screen and then a loading bar) before doing so.     This is supposed to be a traditionally hardcore shooter, but the things that supposedly make it hardcore instead just make it stupid. To make it "hardcore", I'd recommend removing the resurrector completely, reducing the amount of ammo you are allowed to utilize during an individual mission, and then fixing all of the idiocy of the A.I. and polishing the actual mechanics of the game.     It's a solid game, but the issues add up fast. Bugs aren't the issue; I haven't run into a bug yet. The issues lie with the game itself. There is only ever really one approach to beating each mission: kill everything that isn't marked as an ally. The other methods of completing objectives are much harder than mowing down enemies with big guns and grenades, and provide fewer benefits. Hacking a bank dispenser gives you less experience and money than just standing next to the bank dispenser and killing the spawning waves of enemies.     Rating of implementation for various things:Menus? You have to figure them out a bit, but once you do it's simple to see they did a great job here.7/10.Cybernetics? I love that these all actually make sense and that careful observation will show a noticeable difference upon upgrading them. They're much too expensive, however.7/10.Research? The element of mystery is something they should keep, to some degree, but the cost outweighs the benefits most of the time.7/10.Lore? Take Warhammer 10k (not 40k) and then spice it up with some major Deus Ex, then twist the whole thing until it's only recognizable by the threads that link things together. Decent, but a little too vague and washed-out. Also, there's almost zero backstory for any part of the game.6/10.Gameplay? The epic feeling of rolling around in heavy armor with a minigun and trashing hordes of monsters and men alike is interrupted annoyingly every time anyone ever carries an armor-piercing weapon. You cannot survive single-player without heavy armor, either. Every resource uses the same pool of energy, which is a huge detractor from the game for anyone wanting to use psychic powers or even for the folks that want to sprint everywhere to make things go faster. That's it's own point; the game is slow as molasses even though action is constant, which is amazing (in a bad way) in its own right. The game has some pacing issues, and there needs to be a clearer sense of development for the characters you interact with, and that's before mentioning your own personal character lacking any sort of depth beyond "don't trust mentor" and talking to yourself. I'm surprised enemies don't go insane from fighting a juggernaut with a minigun that blew up half their allies into chunks of gore, too, since a single carnophage that does no damage to me (blocked with my sword) made me go insane and start shooting randomly once I pulled out my gun; maintenance as a super easy fix to this actually makes it amusing rather than scary, however... And insanity isn't exactly something I'd prefer to pull my humor from.3/10.Bugs? I haven't found any, but I'm placing "color scheme" here; this is more of a personal issue, but I can't tell apart most things in this game due to the coloration. I can see text and screens in-game, but I cannot see the monsters or people without using cyber vision or the second zoom of the sniper rifle. It's supposed to be cyberpunk and/or steampunk but it really just comes across as dirty and otherwise empty. Upping the brightness doesn't help.7/10.     Overall Rating: I'll put it somewhere around 6/10. It's a decent game, but the group of people that will enjoy it is likely much smaller than the group that will be dissapointed by the difference between the reality of the game and the potential of what it could have been.     It should be noted that the game is pretty cheap, so if you're buying it during a 75% or 50% sale, I would instead recommend it. I mean, it's worth at least $5.

It's supposed to be cyberpunk and/or steampunk but it really just comes across as dirty and otherwise empty. Upping the brightness doesn't help.7/10.     Overall Rating: I'll put it somewhere around 6/10. It's a decent game, but the group of people that will enjoy it is likely much smaller than the group that will be dissapointed by the difference between the reality of the game and the potential of what it could have been.     It should be noted that the game is pretty cheap, so if you're buying it during a 75% or 50% sale, I would instead recommend it. I mean, it's worth at least $5.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Bad things first: Awful, just awful level design. I would expect something like this when i was playing 15 year old games. Levels are huge and empty and just feel confusing as someone with multiple personality disorder would design.Level design is not the only thing that is 15 years old - user interface is also something out of 90's. To open an inventory, you have to hold down C, drag mouse down, let go of C, select inventory from full screen of text and other stuff. There wasnt a way to bind a key to the inventory. Why would you design it like this?Respawning enemies. What were they thinking? I am just curious how the playtesting was, because this makes you constantly out of ammo and makes the stealth almost useless. Aside from the fact that AI's basically have unlimited sight nor does the level design support the stealth.Things that are good:Text is good. It is well written. I enjoyed reading the background lore, but when you are not reading, the levels jump from one location to another and you have no idea what's going on. Conclusion: 15 years behind in level design, UI design and gameplay design. That's a sunken boat that even interesting text could not save. I do not recommend this game. Only buy this if it is on sale and try the demo before you buy.PS: I am probably a minority expressing this opinion of this game. If you like this game then we don't have the same taste in games.

												Very unique experience. Amazing world-building and lore with tons of attention to detail. Gameplay is great and the fps and rpg elements don't intrude/distract from one another. content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												There's very little hook to get you interested in the story, and what little story this title presents is crumbling under the weight of an incompetent or simply nonexistent editor. Don't expect to be emotionally invested in this game, because both the story and the mechanics are both so poorly presented as to be incomprehensible. There might be a really great experience hidden somewhere beneath the broken tutorial system, the completely uninteresting characters, and the mediocre environment design, but this strictly amateur work is turning me off from digging any deeper to try and find it. Forget about "polishing" this, what this title needs is to have the finish stripped, the paint sanded off, and to have the entire user experience reworked from the bare metal.You can tell that a lot of work has been put into the foundational elements of the gameplay - the damage/HP/healing system, the level-up system, the different abilities and weapons, and even the hacking mechanic - but it's all presented in a bland way that makes me think the team got bored with making this game halfway through and decided to phone it in as soon as the levels were designed and the largest bugs in the gameplay were ironed out. It feels like an "Early Access" title that never made it to version 1.0.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I really like E.Y.E., but it isn't exactly a good game.On the one hand, the english translation is pretty terrible, so its almost impossible to understand what you're trying to do at any given time. The tutorial is pretty much a list of videos with unhelpful descriptions and it only gets more confusing from there. Maybe it makes more sense in french, but I doubt it.On the other hand, are there any other games out there where you can kill friend or enemy with a medkit? Are there any where you can try to hack a door and have it hack you back? Use a revolver to take out a helicopter? When was the last time you saw a game featuring rastafarians on mars?If you can get it for around a dollar, I'd say E.Y.E. is worth the time just to see what kind of crazy stuff you'll run into. Co-op is pretty fun too, so if you can convince your friends to split a 4 pack you're in for a pretty good time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Certainly not an easy game to get started with on Normal difficulty with the endless waves of enemies that will once in awhile shoot one another or at another faction, but 90% of time gang up on you if spotted. Tutorial vids are a bit of a joke, the voice acting is all in a made-up language (subtitles for all!), controls are complicated without rebinding, and the over-all feel is that of a mod and not an original, stand-alone title. Biggest gripe I have is the "weapon group" keybinds; every single time you start a game or load a level, they RANDOMIZE what groups they select. So one level your AR, SMG, and swords are 1, 2, 3; next level its your swords, grenades, and medkit on 1, 2, 3; level after that its your AR, grenades, medkit. It's frustrating to rely on the mouse wheel to cycle through ALL your weapons/gear when in a firefight. This is apparent with manual reloading, as its quicker (or SHOULD BE) to change weapons than to reload, especially with something like the minigun or the .50 sniper rifle. But no, unless you're a 2 guns, no gear, player, the wheel will annoy ya. Overall, ONCE YOU GET THE THING GOING, it CAN be fun. Feels like an arena shooter with a poorly written plot. With friends, maybe more so, but solo it does get old quick, and the main campaign isn't easy to follow. Can't honestly say I recomend this game to the pick-up-and-go style players. Fallout 3 was once described as Oblivion with Guns. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is like Morrowind with Guns, but only with it's complexity. So final verdict: nay.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												I bought this game with high hopes seeing as it's received good reviews overall and is made with the Source Engine. After playing it through to the "true" ending, I feel like I can now properly write a review. This game was a HUGE disappointment. The UI is god-awful, the story is confusing and poorly-presented, and the terrible translation job is super distracting. I'm not terribly picky with FPSs. As long as they either have enjoyable gameplay or an engrossing, well-done story, I'm satisfied. E.Y.E fell short in both aspects. I kept hoping the story would begin to come together, but even after reading other players' explanations, I find it poorly done. It's like the developers have an actual interesting idea in mind for what's going on, but they never properly deliver it. Heck, maybe they don't even know wtf is going on in the game. I don't recommend it.
