number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												There is a particular kind of game that one describes as a 'cult classic': It has many, many good features, but these are undermined by the simple fact that, to the unobsessed mind, the game is just bad. For all its brilliant moments, it is still dull.Well, let me tell you, E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy fills that niche like nothing else.Yes, there are good parts, I won't deny that. The combat is fun and diverse, and the hacking and resurrecting systems are so damn clever I found myself wondering why other developers hadn't ripped their ideas off already. It's great stuff, really. Trouble is that's where all the good parts run out.See, the game is French, and the poor translation makes it so that a fellow like me has no hope in hell of understanding the already obscure and tangled plot thanks to terrible, awful translation. Even if it was translated decently I still suspect I wouldn't like it, because the dialouge from the protagonist and like the two permanent characters in the game is this hypermasculine bullcrap that doesn't sound like it could ever come from human mouths. Beyond that, the overlying plot is this whole cliche cyberpunk tangle of mixed metaphors and randomly running into folks from the enemy faction, talking to them, finding that your only responses are insults, and then walking away from them as if you haven't been turning their brethren into crispy giblets for the last couple of hours.Now that might not be a problem if these NPC's were placed in sensible places, but the map design is utter garbage both visually and mechanically, so you'll find these dudes just hangin' around inside bombed-out cafes. The levels are these small nonlinear maps that are lifeless masses of grey and brown palettes with a bit of bad neon slapped in a few places if you're supposed to be in a city. Everything's big, ugly, blocky, and roped off to the point you just really want to stop.And the enemies don't help this either! You mostly fight two different types of humans with no differences between them beyond more ugly or less ugly, and when the token zombie faction shows up its enemies are even worse, consisting of a pink xenomorph clone, a werewolf, a nondescript DOOM demon, and a big dude with hammers that looks like he crawled out of a fantasy game!So, my verdict? Stay away. Buy it if you're curious, but don't expect returns. Expect to crawl through the same environments over and over again, asking yourself if a solid foundation justifies shoddy scaffolding, and finding the same answer every time: NO.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												It feels more like a very ambitious Half Life mod than a full fledged game. Maybe it gets cooler if you put some hours into it, but so far its a very mediocre shooter with clumsily glued-on elements like Hacking and Stealth. I dont mind an amateurish tutorial that informs you from time to time that you should now look up a minimalistic video from another menu.Same thing with the sad AI. Smarter is not automatically better (although the game makes modern FPS bots look like Turing-Test-beating quantum-machines).The terrible pacing- my inner cyborg can still cope. Lots of games have terrible pacing these days.Even E.Y.E.'s  inability to communicate even an excuse of a story is not the final nail in the coffin.What REALLY kills the mood is the terrible art direction. I signed in for some Cyberpunk gawddammit- this is just a mess! Think late 90s FPS: Barely recognizable enemies amidst giant, barrel-filled halls that follow no sensible design or function.The reviewborg shed 1,5/ 5 tears ....in ... rain

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												This game is... Well, I'll just give a brief synopsis.You play as a cyborg ninja-samurai person, who works for an organisation that's pretty much the Illuminati, that's currently preparing for a coup in order to overthrow the intergalactic government. You've recently suffered extreme memory loss due to a mysterious mission you embarked on, and you work for a secret team within your organization aiming to resolve a long-standing rivalry within itself between two major factions (The "Culters" and the "Jians")  by destroying the Jians completely. Meanwhile, your mentor intends to try and bring peace between the two factions, and you're going to have to decide where your loyalties lie.While trying to progress the story and resolve the whole situation, as well as discovering all of your forgotten and darkest secrets, you will enter environments where you can't get more than five seconds of peace before being continously assaulted by horrific entities born from the deepest essences of humanity's impurities, cops, looters, other cyborg ninjas, giant minotaurs with gatling guns that are bigger than a bus, werewolves, or a combination of the six, all in pursuit of the universal RPG goal of making an absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of money so you can keep upgrading your jump height and laugh at the fact your character can now moon-jump across entire maps.You'll also invest your money in funding research, and your researchers should revolutionise the entire universe's perspective on technology around every week. You'll buy new weapons, abilities, psychic powers and implants in order to continously make yourself more powerful. You'll hack sentry guns, ATMs, doors, people, and even yourself (no seriously you can hack yourself). You'll learn how to telefrag your enemies and create clone armies. You'll deploy armies of robots to do your bidding. You'll enslave lesser beings to obey your will. You'll slay monsters ten times as big as yourself.And most importantly, you can run around with a sword that makes people explode when you hit them, and get paid for doing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												There's very little hook to get you interested in the story, and what little story this title presents is crumbling under the weight of an incompetent or simply nonexistent editor. Don't expect to be emotionally invested in this game, because both the story and the mechanics are both so poorly presented as to be incomprehensible. There might be a really great experience hidden somewhere beneath the broken tutorial system, the completely uninteresting characters, and the mediocre environment design, but this strictly amateur work is turning me off from digging any deeper to try and find it. Forget about "polishing" this, what this title needs is to have the finish stripped, the paint sanded off, and to have the entire user experience reworked from the bare metal.You can tell that a lot of work has been put into the foundational elements of the gameplay - the damage/HP/healing system, the level-up system, the different abilities and weapons, and even the hacking mechanic - but it's all presented in a bland way that makes me think the team got bored with making this game halfway through and decided to phone it in as soon as the levels were designed and the largest bugs in the gameplay were ironed out. It feels like an "Early Access" title that never made it to version 1.0.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I really like E.Y.E., but it isn't exactly a good game.On the one hand, the english translation is pretty terrible, so its almost impossible to understand what you're trying to do at any given time. The tutorial is pretty much a list of videos with unhelpful descriptions and it only gets more confusing from there. Maybe it makes more sense in french, but I doubt it.On the other hand, are there any other games out there where you can kill friend or enemy with a medkit? Are there any where you can try to hack a door and have it hack you back? Use a revolver to take out a helicopter? When was the last time you saw a game featuring rastafarians on mars?If you can get it for around a dollar, I'd say E.Y.E. is worth the time just to see what kind of crazy stuff you'll run into. Co-op is pretty fun too, so if you can convince your friends to split a 4 pack you're in for a pretty good time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Certainly not an easy game to get started with on Normal difficulty with the endless waves of enemies that will once in awhile shoot one another or at another faction, but 90% of time gang up on you if spotted. Tutorial vids are a bit of a joke, the voice acting is all in a made-up language (subtitles for all!), controls are complicated without rebinding, and the over-all feel is that of a mod and not an original, stand-alone title. Biggest gripe I have is the "weapon group" keybinds; every single time you start a game or load a level, they RANDOMIZE what groups they select. So one level your AR, SMG, and swords are 1, 2, 3; next level its your swords, grenades, and medkit on 1, 2, 3; level after that its your AR, grenades, medkit. It's frustrating to rely on the mouse wheel to cycle through ALL your weapons/gear when in a firefight. This is apparent with manual reloading, as its quicker (or SHOULD BE) to change weapons than to reload, especially with something like the minigun or the .50 sniper rifle. But no, unless you're a 2 guns, no gear, player, the wheel will annoy ya. Overall, ONCE YOU GET THE THING GOING, it CAN be fun. Feels like an arena shooter with a poorly written plot. With friends, maybe more so, but solo it does get old quick, and the main campaign isn't easy to follow. Can't honestly say I recomend this game to the pick-up-and-go style players. Fallout 3 was once described as Oblivion with Guns. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is like Morrowind with Guns, but only with it's complexity. So final verdict: nay.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												This is some WEIRD game. It has A LOT of things that -at least- could have been done better (some may argue that they're strictly BAD, and maybe they're right). I'm not even sure why i'm recommending it actualy. Maybe because i liked it a lot, even when it left me with a sour taste in my mouth.I'll try to give some pros and cons.Pros (?):+ Its a shooter / "cRPG" hybrid, and a pretty messy one if you're not into some kind of RPG background, but once you get the idea, its kinda cool.+ It has not the best graphics, sounds or music, and yet it gets the job done: it depicts a nasty, lonely and weird dystopic future with [Cyberpunk, Warhammer 40k, Alien, Blade Runner, Matrix, etc] elements. Cool mix if you ask me.+ It has a wide variety of weapons, armor, psi powers, cyber augmentation.+ The hacking minigame its cool. Hard to understand at first maybe.+ Campaign Co-op+ You are part of a faction within a secret order that works for megacorps against the Federation. It consists of Cyber-Psionic warrior-monks that look like Templar Knights and Samurai. YAY! Cons (?):- It throws you into some weird as ♥♥♥♥ situation and doesn't give a single ♥♥♥♥ about you. You're on your own. Tutorial you say? Mmmm... good luck with it. Yeah, sometimes it is a good thing, but E.Y.E. fails at execution here.- The save system may be a pain in the butt.- Pretty weird / bad AI.- The level design its great... but sometimes they are HUUUUGE and E M P T Y, devoid of any sign of life. Good concept maybe, terrible execution for sure.- Poor story and background development, althoug i like it (more about this later)- You are part of a faction within a secret order that works for megacorps against the Federation. It consists of Cyber-Psionic warrior-monks that look like Templar Knights and Samurai. WTF?I may be missing something, but you get the idea by now.Now, one last, important and HUGE point: the key is the ending. All this whole mess of a game makes sense (and be warned, not necessarily a good one) when you reach the "end". The actual one. After you've completed the game AT LEAST three times. This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ lets you wonder WTF just happened and, again, it doesn't give a single ♥♥♥♥ about you, your feelings, your expectations. Anything. And i like that. What were you expecting? This has some heavy cyberpunk influences after all!But seriously, the end demands you to think about the whole experience, something that not many games do.So, to get this to an end, should you buy E.Y.E?Only if you can see through some far-from-perfect indie game, if you like cyberpunk, weird and not so conclusive stories.If you're in doubt, wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Editing-- and am early in my "career" into this one because it delivers.Only a few short hours into this unique experience of a RPG / FPS, and I find myself falling in love.There almost nothing missing, and thoroughly adds more to the genre than most (a sense of zone and melee as you will drop your gun barrel or blade low, for instance).Interface is a little bizzare and unoccomodating at first but is a beautiful tapestry of the art theme, to which this game looks grand and psychological.I immediately felt welcomed though with the tuturoials (wiki and community is really helpful and necessary), if not immediately challenged the dangerous world of E.Y.E. where an alien world is at the very heart of a surreal and deep plot of warring factions and hightened sense of mechanical combat.This game came out in a good year when FPS games were starting to spread wings, and this game flew sky high, if unnoticed by many.Recommended?  DEFINITELY!For everyone?  Not necessarily, I like the pace, but we pick our own poisons~But... if you enjoy cyberpunk, gothic / victorian themes, massive architecture, Blade Runner, Shadowrun, Warhammer, Deus Ex-like themes this game has the best and funnest features of each of these and is so pleasing to the eye.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												E.Y.E Divine Cybermancy.Man, what to say about THIS game.Is it a Warhammer 40,000 rip-off, or something else entirley?It is BOTH. E.Y.E. Divine Cybermancy is a First Person Shooter/Role Playing Game hybrid, that takes influence from Deus Ex, Warhammer 40,000, System Shock 1&2, Ancient Japanese Samuri lore (I think), and the book Dune.This is one of those games that comes along once in a while, that shows a REAL depth and attention to lore and universe in a way not seen since Halo, Warhammer 40,000 or Doom, but it too complex and confusing to really catch the E.Y.E. (pun intended) of the average gamer today. It is made at a time when people who mde games for the PC MADE it FOR the PC. As such you should remember 90% of the buttons on the keybord or use 5 different options menus.  So as you can tell, Deus Ex is a big influence on E.Y.E. You play as an Agent for the secret society E.Y.E. as they try to stop a fight between two rival factions.To be honest the story was confusing to me, and maybe if I spent more time focused and payed more attention to what's going on, I would of got the story.Like you REALLY have to be COMPLETELY FOCUSED and IMERSED into the story to make sense of it, and it can be a bit off putting.The gameplay is like Warhammer 40,000 meets Deus Ex. If you have played System Shock 1&2 and/or Deus Ex, you should know what to expect from this game.That's all I've got to say about this game.Play it. You'll either get a great & enjoyable experiance, or a confusing, unenjoyable one instead.Broken 3/5"A beutifully ambitious broken masterpiece"

												I love the open level design of the game which gives ya multiple choices on how to take on each mission whether it be charging head on guns blazing, or using stealth tactics to assassinate each target. Adding onto that exploration in each level is highly encouraged as  side missions, secrects, and such are to be had. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Heres da thing. Its a grass roots indie game developed by a small international studio using the source engine. This means several things: bad translation, rough presentation, bugs, and a very dated look. The game sometimes feel more like a mod to another game, then an actual game of it's own. You would be tempted to think then,  that the game is rubbish. It's not. In fact, it's a blast. Because when things do come together (and they do more often then not) its a really well done piece with plenty ambitious ideas. I would warn you though, this game is not for the faint of heart or for those who expect to some level of handholding at first. This initially turned me off of the game years ago. I see now though, after sticking with it, this is a great game and if you are fan of cyberpunk-likes then I think you would enjoy it too.

content:

												This surprisingly well made game built on the Source Engine is challenging, fun, and a great multiplayer game. I bought a four-pack without knowing whether or not this game would be any fun. The learning curve, even for an FPS game, it tough due to it's rudimentary UI and RPG-hardened gameplay. Overall though, it's a great game that even RPG-haters like me can appreciate. The art style is the best I've seen on Source, and the singleplayer/multiplayer will keep you on for more than 40 hours.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Fantastic game concept, great models and textures and original sound effects. One of the most creative and original FPS games to ever be designed. It has a plot with a rich backstory!The downside? Unplayable. Endless waves of cheater AI destroy your character with no break in the abuse, from the minute you step into a level. No room for strategy. Just endless, pointless hack-and-slash....except your character is the only one hacked up and slashed. The skills system is completely pointless and you will never have the opportunity to use it--all you will be doing is taking a beating from an endless cavaclade of indestructible cheater-AI bots.I searched desperately for a patch, thinking the game had serious bugs that have since be resolved, only to find out that the gameplay balance is seriously broken by design. What a bitter disappointment.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2011
												For the price of the game, it's quite a deal (right now of course, when the deals' still on). The gameplay is heavily dependent on your play style, with new "tools" such as (hacking and psi abilities) at hand, you choose how you want to play and how you handle certain situations; stealth assassinations, rushes, hacking, and many more as shown in the trailer.The game is fun but can sometimes be a lil' frustrating due to the new key binds unlike HL2's (e.g. "Activate" is <Enter> as opposed to <e> in HL2). Also, with the new UI; weapons, skills, hacks and psi the game may be quite confusing to new birds however there are tutorial videos built right in the game.Weapons ranges from swords to shotguns to minigun but may be underpowered. Ammo is abundant as armories are almost everywhere.Graphics-wise is somewhat improved from the original HL2 series but not as good as current games.Game is still buggy but I guess it'll be fixed soon with regular updates as this is a promising game.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												  Such an interesting game. Sure it has literally the roughest start to any game I've ever played, but once you surpass that obstacle, you then realize you have found a game that you will remember for being so weird, interesting, and incredibly fun.  The amount of freedom you have to make your character strong is unbelievable, I ended up making a quick medic that uses heavy weapons, but dies quickly.  The story is very interesting aswell, atleast, if you enjoy reading in on alot of stuff. Though I highly recommend you do, it's certainly not one I'd forget anytime soon.  Sure graphics are dated, but the locations are so interesting, plus the music is pretty good, and sets the mood really well.  Also, it supports coop, coop generally makes things more fun, so if you can, bring a friend!  I highly recommend this game, it's weird, which is why I love it.

												E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy is not really the best of games, but it really depends on what you enjoy. 												A strange game of a sort you don't see much these days. Its core strength is the gameplay. The game sets you loose in large open levels, while providing an assortment of toys and powers to mess around in whatever way you see fit. In regards to the story it is better to just go with the flow, soaking in the atmosphere while not trying too hard to figure out what is going on. It isn't a game that will appeal to everyone, but in its own little niche it shines.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												You thought Ghost in the Shell was hard to comprehend?Welcome to E.Y.E.An FPS/RPG cyberpunk cluster♥♥♥♥ where nothing is explained properly, all wrapped in charming Engrish.And boy is it fun.The game allows an extreme variety of playstyles, all completly viable.Runnig at 10 sanics across the map with your katana folded a thousand times over slicing every moving thing in sight? Sure.A covert invisible infiltrator? Why not.A Big Guy with a warhammer and a minigun, staring the danger in the face as you obliterate them? Go on.Hacking the enemies to turn them against each other, avoiding direct combat whenever possible? Completly possible. Just be wary, THE DOORS CAN HACK YOU BACK. YES, YOU CAN BE COUNTER-HACKED BY DOORS.Becoming a cyberpunk magican to make your enemies explode while suffering from hallucinations? Got you covered.A more conventional FPS playstyle with guns and taking cover? WHY WOULD YOU DO THAT but yes you can.Go gain some Brouzouf.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												A variety of characteristics and odd design elements that shouldn't work, but work amazingly.  Combat is fast paced like Doom, but with more modern elements (aim down sights, various psionic options, placable turrets...).  There's an RPG element sort of like Deus Ex, but not at all like Deus Ex.  It's translated from French, but intended to be a futuristic mode of speech, so it's hard to know what's translation errors and what's just supposed to be atmospheric.   Everything should make this a mediocre game, but it's amazing.  If you don't love this game you are probably a horrible person who hates fun.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Product received for free
												I'll try to be a brief as possible.I literally don't know where to start, but i guess that the first impression that this game gave me is of a huge unfinished project; but I understimated whatever that got finished.This is a game that will take you from "not knowing how to open a door" to "fight colossal monsters on the surface of mars".And i think that the part of the game that got me involved the most was trying to figure out how the game worked; and of course the realisation that the key for a true experience was the replayability the game has, in which of course you have a vast variety of guns and skills to shape your style however you want. And of course a lovely progression system built around brouzoufs.To sum up.Play it, get frustated, keep playing, gain brozoufs, get some friends, check your legs, grain more brouzouf, enjoy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												A simple yet impressive game that has one of the most interesting atmopsheres and feels to it of any game I've played. I would call the feeling I get from it similar to the one you get from the atmosphere from Dark Souls but different in it's own unique way to where it's not the same feel in an fps. As an avid fan of Warhammer 40k games this game gives you a seemingly copyright infringingly close experience to games of those vein but less of the Space Marine machismo and more of the simple pathetic human thrown against the tides of space. Game is rather unpolished, but that some how adds to it's charm in generating that unique feel. Overall 7/10, a bit of spit shine and polish of the game design, character advancement, and in a few other areas and would easily be 9/10, but still overall a very fun and rewarding experience.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A very strange yet unique and intriguing game.  The game has you playing as a secret agent working for a shadow corporation of some sorts working for another shadow corporation, I think.  The story and back story are the most interesting things in the game.  They did a very good job with the plot, history, and setting up an immersive world.  The gameplay is its weakest point but still very enjoyable if you spend the time to learn it.  What I mean by this is it basically just drops you into the game, with the ability to level, research, melee, sneak, hack, etc from the get go with an optional tutuorial that is confusing and doesnt explain things in well enough detail.Honestly it took me about 3 hours to learn how to play the damn game, but once you get there its a blast.  On normal it feels a bit easy though, balance is not this games best feature.  If you can get past its flaws in the gameplay, it has a very indepth story and universe that will make you play it for hours and hours.

I pick up ammo, but it doesn't re-load the guns...I also can't re-load wepons.   A "life" counter would help.  Really a waste of money.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												E.Y.E.: Divine Cybermany is an interesting game where the developers tried to cram as many features into it as possible. Best description I can come up with is the original Deus Ex with a healthy dose of Anarchy Online after binging on Warhammer 40k lore and William Gibson's Neuromancer. The Story takes place in the grim-dark of "whatever the hell year". You are an agent of the Culter Dei who is rivaled by and allied with Jian. Both who are part of E.Y.E, that is the militant portion of Secreta Secretorum. A cult/government/secret society. That everyone seems to know about. You fight against many different factions, each who hate eachother just a little bit less then you as they have no problem concentrating their efforts on you rather then eachother. There are the "looters"; space pirates on bath salts, basically. The Federation. An oppressive government that is never actually shown ever doing any oppressing. Just trying to kill some cult fanatics, looters and "demons". And the "metastreumonic forces", who are... something. Demons, manifetations of emotions, nature fighting back. Take your pick.Gameplay itself is a  solid First-Person Shooter that will feel very familiar to those who have played the original Deus Ex at any lenght. If only a bit smoother. Your movement is influenced by everything. What you wear and carry, how advanced some skills and implants are and what kind of injuries you have sustained. Though at times it does feel like your character is moving on ice, it in general feels very smooth and well made. Controls can get a bit overwhelming at times as there are quite a few buttons to keep in mind. Movement, skills, leaning and weapon functions take up quite a bit and it can feel daunting to remember the essentials beyond movement but it is nothing too complicated. Character development is extremely deep with the stats system being influenced by the implants you have and their level of advancement, and what researches you have done with the randomly generated pickups that enemies drop every once in a while. Stats themselves seem to not have a cap as far as I have seen and the benefits they give just keep going up the more points you put in. To the point that if you go on long enough, you'll be jumping 20m into the air in the heaviest armor, wielding the heaviest weapons and running around at mach 2, absorbing rockets and armor piercing bullets with your face while your health bar refuses to budge. Best place for a Deadpool in Ironman armor imitation. Also to note is that when replaying the story, your character retains progress. Meaning every play-through will make you progressively more powerful as you level up and sink points and money into your skills and implants. The AI, however is both smart and stupid at the same time. Unable to open doors, but very capable of taking cover and flushing you out with expertly thrown grenades and not from Storm Trooper Scool. They are also completely incapable of any other action but charging right at you in combat. Thankfully the game lets you tweak how many enemies spawn and how often. But even on modest and lower settings the game can still sometimes feel like you were playing a first person StarCraft game against the Zerg as there will be a steady stream of tireless, seeking, flesh-missiles jumping out of walls behind you. Thankfully, even on the higher difficulty settings, guns are very capable in killing the enemy in a few well placed shots. Very little in the way of "Bulletsponges" in the game, though they exist. But you can also make yourself equally spongy and twice as deadly so it sort of balances out. The environments you go to are in general very bleak looking. Very dystopian, channeling Blade Runner and select few animes, but unique. Mostly urban landscapes, but with enough variety to allow you to play anything from a sniper to a melee fighter. And anything in between. The game's age does show itself in the art and textures. As does it show the age of the Source engine. At some moments you will notice very high quality textures and assets mixed in with some very simple ones. In fact some parts in the maps look more like they were made in the original Unreal engine. But You won't really have time to notice all that as you'll be hip deep in enemies who can blend into the environment. Enemy visuals tend to repeat as there are only a handful of head and body types per faction with a few additional attachments. But that still makes enemies more varied then in most other AAA titles currently on the market. In conclusion.This game is flawed. But it is fun. A convoluded but still followable plot demands that you play it through more then once and with the sheer mass of choices you can make in both dialogue and rest of the gameplay give a lot of replayability. Allowing you to become the warrior you want to be in any imaginable combination of skills and weapons or lack thereof. A solid game well worth the price and time to play. If anything, a guilty pleasure game to play when burned out on everything else. Wholly recommend.

												Fantastic game concept, great models and textures and original sound effects. One of the most creative and original FPS games to ever be designed. It has a plot with a rich backstory!The downside? Unplayable. Endless waves of cheater AI destroy your character with no break in the abuse, from the minute you step into a level. No room for strategy. Just endless, pointless hack-and-slash....except your character is the only one hacked up and slashed. The skills system is completely pointless and you will never have the opportunity to use it--all you will be doing is taking a beating from an endless cavaclade of indestructible cheater-AI bots.I searched desperately for a patch, thinking the game had serious bugs that have since be resolved, only to find out that the gameplay balance is seriously broken by design. What a bitter disappointment.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												  Such an interesting game. Sure it has literally the roughest start to any game I've ever played, but once you surpass that obstacle, you then realize you have found a game that you will remember for being so weird, interesting, and incredibly fun.  The amount of freedom you have to make your character strong is unbelievable, I ended up making a quick medic that uses heavy weapons, but dies quickly.  The story is very interesting aswell, atleast, if you enjoy reading in on alot of stuff. Though I highly recommend you do, it's certainly not one I'd forget anytime soon.  Sure graphics are dated, but the locations are so interesting, plus the music is pretty good, and sets the mood really well.  Also, it supports coop, coop generally makes things more fun, so if you can, bring a friend!  I highly recommend this game, it's weird, which is why I love it.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												EYE:Divine Cybermancy is this weird little pseudo-gem of a game. In a way it's like Deus Ex, but multiplayer, but also janky as hell and buggy to high heaven.The Plot:The story makes pretty much no sense at all, and all the characters are weirdly aggresive towards you if you ask questions-- even though it is established and widely known you have some sort of memory loss. "Why would memory loss factor into the plot?" you may be asking, well... that is because there is hardly anything in this game that it can expect you to understand. The plot is bonkers, things happen with no warning at all. It's sort of cyberpunk, but also sort of old-timey, but also sort of post-future-pre-futuristic (???). Basically the sort of plot where futuristic cyber-nuns fight a bunch of police officers but they use street-slang for some reason whenever they talk about them. The translations in general will make you go "Um...Okay, I don't understand this at all." and then a man with a gun will shoot you in the face and you will enter a coma. The maximum number of comas is 10, unless you upgrade your number of comas. Yes. Exciting.Gameplay:The gameplay has that floaty feeling that all source games seem to have, but there are lean mechanics, a hacking minigame, stealth, and a ton of augments. They're all fairly broken, but it's nice that they decided to pay a visit. Enemies will wreck you, this is a standard of EYE. Even if you upgrade your guns and armor, you are a fragile little pool noodle and your enemies shoot a million shots a second with pinpoint accuracy. At higher difficulty levels your augments will mean nothing (Unless you can always cloak, cloak is good).Overall:EYE:Divine Cybermancy is a janky, buggy, bonkers homage to Cyberpunk RPGs blended with a metric buttload of other things, pushed back and forth through google translate 7-10 times. If someone remade this game without the bad bits, and made some of the less fun features of the game (ie. Hacking is boring as hell, but you need it a lot) more fun, I would be in heaven. For now however, I highly recommend this game for a confusing, bonkers, but mostly fun experience.

												You know, I actually bought this game when it came out, I still remember how the trailer showcased the different ways to defeat enemies. When I saw the dragon spell I was sold, who doesn't want to enter another's body in an explosion of gore? But that aside, this game has provided me with hours of entertainment, the characters are interesting and the storyline really draws you in, mix that with the almost trippy soundtrack and it will feel like everything IS just a dream. I must also say that it is awesome alone or with a friend, unfortunately the online servers are pretty much dead, so it is unlikely that you find a versus map. But if you do, it is really a blast. 10/10

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												A simple yet impressive game that has one of the most interesting atmopsheres and feels to it of any game I've played. I would call the feeling I get from it similar to the one you get from the atmosphere from Dark Souls but different in it's own unique way to where it's not the same feel in an fps. As an avid fan of Warhammer 40k games this game gives you a seemingly copyright infringingly close experience to games of those vein but less of the Space Marine machismo and more of the simple pathetic human thrown against the tides of space. Game is rather unpolished, but that some how adds to it's charm in generating that unique feel. Overall 7/10, a bit of spit shine and polish of the game design, character advancement, and in a few other areas and would easily be 9/10, but still overall a very fun and rewarding experience.

												A strange game of a sort you don't see much these days. Its core strength is the gameplay. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												9/10 Would buy again.Probably one of the most underrated shooter/rpg/open world games out today.  The story behind this game is great and I love the combat system, solid controls and gameplay, great active online multiplayer, and community is still active as well. The campaign missions are very fun and can always be completed in multiple ways.  The combat in addition to the conversation choices you make in missions, or in-between missions, do inflict what happens in others, not only in conversation like what mainly happened in the Mass Effect Series with your background and initial choice with that, but also in events in some missions.  The combat is balanced, you can choose various types of playstyles from melee/close quarters, to sniping, and anything in-between.  There is a wide selection of weapons and even more enememies to kill as you play the game.There is a hacking mini game that can be as big or as small a part of the game as you want.  You can use your skills to upgrade your abilities to further gain information for a mission, enhance the story, or complete a mission in an alternate manner, it all depends on how much effort you put in.Solid online games and co-op as well. There are various Steam groups that do co-op events and online events.  The events that happen online affect your single player character as well.  You can level up online and increase your skills offline, and gain some small experience points and money for offline use, but the effects are still noticeable.This single player and multiplayer link means there is a sort of drm, in that the account your start your game with and use in your campaign will be the same one as online.  That being said, it is really just like a save game, you can have multiple ones and switch between then with ease.This game is worth full price, and if nothing else, just enjoy it for the multiplayer if you are not into that whole adventure story free roam kind of thing.*A feature I've found when I play that the only way the game saves is at the start of a mission, at least I haven't found a way to save manually, but the missions can be completed as quickly or take as long as you want, depending on how you play, so take that into account when you sit down for another go at gaming.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												I bought this game with the hopes that I, a young broken soul, would finally be able to smite my foes and feel an inhuman feeling of pure joy surge through every single ♥♥♥♥ing neuron in my being. That I would finally be able to put my withered broken body to something that would bring me happiness and joy, as this world has failed to do. This game was going to be a lifeline to the outside world, I was ready to be made alive once again. I slowly moved my shaking finger over the glowing "Play" button and clicked, anticipation and anxiety overtaking me as I broke into sobs that ricocheted through out my body. I regained my shattered composure and looked up at my moniter through blearly and red eyes. The developers logo flashed and lit up my darkened room. The level loaded and I was overtaken by the immense beauty and incredible scenery of this incredible work of art. I equiped myself with a katana that looked like a polished diamond in my character's gloved hands. I pressed my tear stained "w" key and moved forward. I was looking down at an incredible dam like structure, with an enemy patrol talking amongst themselves at ankle level water that looked as though it had been hand crafted in the hands of a god. I held my shift key and catapulted myself into the thick of the enemies, launching into the air like a majestic bird taking a flight for his first time, stretching my wings that had taken billions of years of evolutionary success to be made to accommodate my every need. I felt like a sentient being towering over, preparing to remove them from the gene pool with the force of an intergalatic explosion.  i then broke my legs and was shot to death while i was unconscious 10/10 best game ever played

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Bluntly - this game is a mess. Now, don't get me wrong: I love RPGs and FPS. I love Cyberpunk, sci-fi, Warhammer 40k, Blade Runner, Robocop, Deus Ex and pretty much everything else that this game was supposed to be a combination/comparison of according to other reviews.But the sad truth is that this isn't supposed to be some sort of insane, sci-fi acid trip; this is supposed to be an open world RPG with FPS elements, more akin to Fallout style game play, but instead what you get is barely intelligible English shoved into an over complicated plot and combined with FPS and open world mechanics from about 10 years ago.For example, if you do 1HP damage to a friendly NPC by accidentally setting off a power (which was poorly explained anyway), then everyone in the area will stop at nothing to kill you. You either kill everyone and annihilate any semblance of plot, or you die, either way it's game over. 20 minutes into the game, you'll suddenly find yourself doing a lot of reading as a bunch of characters start spewing the basic world premise at you. Various mysteries start to appear, relationships start to materialise, motivations become apparent... all within a few extremely large chunks of texts that are very difficult to decipher in broken English.It's not all terrible: the world itself is fairly interesting and original. I will not take that away from the creative forces behind this game - they have made something truly different which they are obviously very passionate about. And the saddest thing is that if this had been picked up by a large games developer and given a multi-million dollar budget then, wow, this game could have an instant cult classic.As is, it's just a big mess of outdated indie amateurism and I'm afraid to say that I think a lot of these good reviews just come from the fact that is a large and very cheap game - the kind of thing that appeals to kids and people unwilling to spend £30 on a polished, up to date title. So sure, if your gaming budget hasn't allowed for anything by Bethsada in the last 15 years, then get E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy and maybe you'll like it. Otherwise, I wouldn't bother.

												This is a dangerous game where you can suffer from the horrible disease known as Sulfatum addiction where you become bodily ill unless you are holding down the trigger on a bulky minigun gunning down lootersSulfatum addiction patients may also suffer from a holy-♥♥♥♥-this-smg-has-a-second-fire-mode complication with their disease, allowing them to violently eject their magazines through the barrel.Those with sulfatum addiction may recover, eventually becoming ridiculously fast blurs of katana-wielding death that simply don't need a gun to deal with anything the game throws at them.If you get past the gun fun, you can get yourself confused by the game's lore, which is surprisingly deep and has spawned some frustration and speculation from fans. There are also two levels that are cyberpunk enough to tide me over until Cyberpunk 2077 comes out. It's a rough game yes and it really shows sometimes but as a first mainstream game, it shows a lot of promise.Also, this game has a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of references. The devs must have had some fun making this.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2011
												E.Y.E. Devine Cybermancy - I was VERY sceptical about this game. It simply sounded too good to be true, the discription was too ambitious for it to work I thought. Than I've read that it was indie game made by 10 people.I was than SURE it's not going to be any good. Than I've read those 10 people were Franch, suddenly I thought - hah, it propably can't even be called a real game!What can I say? I was totally wrong, the game is actually genious, despite some flaws that I think will be repaired soon enough. The game is addictive, despite using old Source game, instead of UnrealEngine like "the good stuff" these days. Game is very complex at beginning, but after a while it's almost intuitive in every way. Creators also seem to be reacting to the community and they wish to perfect the game, so I can recommend this game to just about anyone - perfect blend of RPG and FPS, allows players to use different approaches, playestyles, solo or multi-player mode.IN SHORT: BUY IT!

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												EYE: Divine Cybermancy has you fill the boots of a special agent working with a special forces group in a world strife with political backstabbing. That said, I wouldn't consider plot to be the biggest pull to this game. Between the wide variety of weapons, hacking, psionics, stealth, and mechanical augments, the game is a veritable playground, with each mission being able to be completed in a variety of ways: Slowly hacking into the augmented brains of your enemies and turning them into mindless slaves to act as your meat shields to wearing heavy armor and mowing down hordes with a minigun, or even using psychic powers to fling broken cars across the map. Perhaps the most alluring aspect of the game is the power the protagonist can obtain, vaguely reminiscent of Deus EX, you have no conventional classes, and your progressive character building eventually results in an incredibly powerful, flexible--or specialized--protagonist. The main campaign can be played alone, or with friends on LAN, moreover, there's competitive PvP gamemodes to keep things fresh. The game itself is fairly adequate in length, requiring six to ten hours to complete, but with endings for four complete playthroughs. Moreover, your characters will maintain from one gamemode to another, so if you play multi-player a lot, you can then port your character to the main campaign, or load it in to play with a friend in co-operative missions. As such, the same character can be made to play through the game multiple times, hitting ever high levels of power until you're jumping over apartment buildings and slicing through gunships with a Katana--that's also a demonic cyborg.If you enjoy things like Warhammer 40k, Ghost in the Shell, or Shadowrun, this is likely the game for you with its dystopian cyberpunk FPS/RPG themes. While the plot, gameplay, and atmosphere holds up for solo play, the game is best done with a group of friends.

												Really unique game, I love the whole world. I feel as though they could make a second game with this exact same engine, maybe improve upon the general complaints like AI. I feel as though the tutorial would be a huge improvement as this game does sort of throw you into it. But once you get into the game a bit, you learn as you go. For $10, I can't say that it's not worth the risk.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												A very strange yet unique and intriguing game.  The game has you playing as a secret agent working for a shadow corporation of some sorts working for another shadow corporation, I think.  The story and back story are the most interesting things in the game.  They did a very good job with the plot, history, and setting up an immersive world.  The gameplay is its weakest point but still very enjoyable if you spend the time to learn it.  What I mean by this is it basically just drops you into the game, with the ability to level, research, melee, sneak, hack, etc from the get go with an optional tutuorial that is confusing and doesnt explain things in well enough detail.Honestly it took me about 3 hours to learn how to play the damn game, but once you get there its a blast.  On normal it feels a bit easy though, balance is not this games best feature.  If you can get past its flaws in the gameplay, it has a very indepth story and universe that will make you play it for hours and hours.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2011
												E.Y.E. Devine Cybermancy - I was VERY sceptical about this game. It simply sounded too good to be true, the discription was too ambitious for it to work I thought. Than I've read that it was indie game made by 10 people.I was than SURE it's not going to be any good. Than I've read those 10 people were Franch, suddenly I thought - hah, it propably can't even be called a real game!What can I say? I was totally wrong, the game is actually genious, despite some flaws that I think will be repaired soon enough. The game is addictive, despite using old Source game, instead of UnrealEngine like "the good stuff" these days. Game is very complex at beginning, but after a while it's almost intuitive in every way. Creators also seem to be reacting to the community and they wish to perfect the game, so I can recommend this game to just about anyone - perfect blend of RPG and FPS, allows players to use different approaches, playestyles, solo or multi-player mode.IN SHORT: BUY IT!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I dunno, man.On one hand, there's a large amount of grinding evolved. Enough that you will actually learn all the paths of the levels, which is a feat of itself! They're huge!The game is incredibly well done. It's very grim and dark, and carries a really strong tone of cyberpunk.It's absolutely a hot mess of game, I've more than a few times crashed near the end of grind-missions, and the story is hard to understand, even with a mod that translates the game better than the♥♥♥♥♥♥poor translation.Then you replay the first large city level and get completely immersed in the opening music track that play once you emerge from the door, and it all comes full circle.An absolute gem that only satsifies a few niche gamers, but something everyone should experience. It's basically deus ex anywaysThe first playthrough is absolutely awful if you take the path of Grey Master and become a jack of all trades. You end up majoring in nothing and it takes longer to unlock the things you want.After the first playthrough and character, the game immediately opens up. You can do nothing but put all points into one specific stat and actually main that stat, so you can become a pure hacker/PSI force user, pure tank, pure speed, anything.Amazing once you figure out the gameplay and how it works. Until then, however, it's very frustrating with deaths and stat loss on death sometimes and other things.Also, once you figure out that the real fun is having a low mental balance stat, it adds to it.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												E.Y.E is an obtuse and inane mess of half-baked ideas. It's an interesting idea suffocated by high concept and poor design. Nothing about E.Y.E is intuitive; the game would rather flood you with useless exposition than introduce you to new ideas in a digestable fashion. It's really a shame, too, because E.Y.E has potential. Stylistically, it's a standout title; it takes the cyberpunk aesthetic and drapes it atop a psuedo-knightly religious sensibility. It brings an atmosphere that is undeniably intoxicating. It offers players a number of options in regards to play style and objectives, which is always a point of praise in my book. Despite being visually engaging, the levels in E.Y.E are maddeningly large, sparsely populated, and there is no map function. Enemies are wildly inconsistent, in some missions you'll encounter colourful multiple armed creatures, the xenomorph from Alien and.. werewolves? There's no explanation. It just happens. The tonal shift is jarring, moving from oppressive looking storm troopers to colourful aliens and then back again without rhyme or reason.E.Y.E's story-telling is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ atrocious. I'm not sure if there's a good story in E.Y.E, because I understood literally nothing it threw at me. What's a Brouzouf? Meta-streumonic? Jians? Federation? It is a confusing mess of high concept sci-fi that seems more concerned with sounding exotic and unique than actually being comprehensible.I don't think E.Y.E is terrible. I actually think it's an okay game, but it's infuriating to see such potential muddied by avoidable design disasters. If the developers had eased the player into the mechanics and the lore, if they'd cut the fat off maps and made them compact and rich instead of large and vacuous, E.Y.E would be a knockout.I can't recommend E.Y.E. However, I really hope there is a sequel or follow up at some point, and the developers take the strengths of this game and pour them into something more carefully designed. I mean that. I hope this is just the beginning, and that in the near future we get to experience this world again.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												Althought the concept of a farflung (or alternate) time when religion and technology are one and the same is intriguing, the game itself is horrid. The UI is clunky, at best. The dialogue (since it's mostly an rpg, there's a ton of it) is all in large blocks of text using language that's sort of confusing at first (they don't speak english). The controls are abyssmal. The inventory managment is pretty damned bad, as you can only fit the guns and ammo you need into a weird man-shaped block set up, as well as being required to look directly at whatever you want to pick up, which sucks during combat. And we come to the center of the shrubbery maze. For also being an FPS, the combat is terrible. A silenced sniper head-shot from far enough away that the second zoom must used to see the target, WILL draw every infintly spawning enemy from the entire area. Once you're spotted, there is no hiding. They will find you. As a disclaimer, this is being typed out after playing it for hours and only getting to level 9. I'm hoping my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ time is because the attempted stealth/hacking play style isn't well suited to being low level, or I just can't figure out how the hell to level up in the way I want to. If it ever goes on sale again for $5 or less, try it, until then, avoid it.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												This game has some very cool ideas, but overall, poor excecution. The setting and atmosphere are wonderful (despite the relatively unsophisticated graphics), and the soundtrack does well to create a unique experience. The RPG elements of this came are complex, offering a great amount of potential depth. However, said elements remain mostly unexplained, which leads to confusion on the part of the player. This is most apparent when it comes to the 'hacking' minigame. The poorly translated dialogue and abstract plot only add to this effect. My biggest gripe, however, is the ending. The finale of any game ought to be reminiscent of standard gameplay; the player feels a sense of mastery, while their newly acquired skills are put to one last test. E.Y.E. mostly consists of sparesly populated levels, in which the player engages generic enemies in small numbers. The final level thrusts you into fighting groups of over a dozen concentrated enemies, with little warning or preparation. After slogging my way through the boss fight (a big mob of generic enemies with one slightly tougher generic enemy in the middle), I discovered that the true ending is only possible after completing the entire campaign thrice. I have no desire to work my way through the same levels again. I promptly uninstalled E.Y.E.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2011
												It's like an insane over the top Deus Ex, stuffed into a Serious Sam game, heavily inspired by Warhammer 40k, made by people who a) don't speak English and b) are French.Don't mistake this for merely a pretty jolly game, it's one of the best FPS campaign experiences on Steam. Like Serious Sam, Duke 3D and so on before it, the entire game can be played in coop. The not very long campaign has a few branch situations, and in general mission objectives are slightly flexible as to which ones you complete and how you go about it, so the game has a whole bunch of replay value. You can play as many playthroughs as you want with your character.The game isn't afraid of being hard and making you die, and as there's semipermanent (i.e. not easily fixable) death penalties eventually, it also strongly encourages playing well.Be aware that singleplayer and multiplayer campaign progress are saved separately in your character file, so you cannot start a game on your own and continue with others (unless you start it as a MP game and play alone). One player is the campaign host in multiplayer, this is separate from the actual server host.(There's also competitive MP nowadays, but I don't think anybody's ever played it.)

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												I've tried to like EYE, I really wanted to like EYE. I waited for the game to be patched, I've tried the fan text revamp. But in the end the entire game is just so obtuse, esoteric, and poorly put together it just all falls apart.The levels are often far too large for what is in them (the hub level is this to the extreme), and and the lack of a map and any clear indicators as to what is intercative or not adds more confusion along with the poor lighting. The enemy spawn system is a nightmare and the gunplay is ok at best. The plot is also a gibbering mess that would give Stanley Kubrick a headache.In the end I'd give it a 3.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												I honestly don't get this game. I like the visual style and the cryptic atmosphere, but nothing else in it is compelling enough for me to play it.I don't see how this is an RPG. Because there are stats and you occasionally get to pick an answer in a cringeworthy dialogue? Maybe 4h is not enough to judge, but from what I've played this is a shooter, and not a very good one at that. There's nothing terribly wrong with it, but the interface is very clunky and everything else is just kinda mediocre. The psychic stuff seems kinda nice, but thanks to the clunky interface I was just shooting everything with the same gun and it worked 100%. Ammo is effectively unlimited, every mission has a "gun case" where you can pick up whatever you like, as long as you bought it (just once) earlier in your base. You also respawn when you die, I think it has limited resurrections, but I just don't feel like playing to find out what happens when you run out. Enemies respawn too. It's like they were designing a multiplayer only shooter and then changed their mind and tried to make a singleplayer/co-op game with a story, but it was already too late to fix the gameplay to reflect that (or to add the story for that matter).The game does a terrible job at explaining anything, which is acceptable when it comes to the story, but less so when all you get in terms of tutorial is a collection of short video presentations on some gameplay subjects. They didn't even link the videos to what's happening in the game, it will just occasionally say “press T to view tutorial” when it really means “press T and pick the right video from the list for this situation, we couldn't be bothered to do it”.If you want to play a shooter in a weird setting with a cryptic (or maybe just poorly explained) story and you get this on sale for 1€/$ like I did, it's maybe worth a shot, you're not risking much, but I don't recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												E.Y.E. can be described in only one sentence:"great idea, horrible esecution".It has some neat ideas, like the way you can customize your pg and loadout, but it lacks "the gasp". You have to dive in the lore trough not exactly the best speeches ever written to understand what the hell is going on around you. And even then, all you'll get will be a sad excuse of lore, a more cybernetic Warhammer 40k like universe, twisting and collapsing around its fallacies.And don't let me start about the gameplay and the mechanics. GOD, the level design is boring, the AI's just plain dumb and, since it seems to run on a capped version of the Source Engine, random things, borderline enough to not be called glitches, will happen.Tl;dr: sendthisasagifttoyourworstenemy/10

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												It's entirely possible that with a group of friends and a lack of other games to play, I could get into this, but as it stands I have so many other things that are so much more worthy of my time.From the little I've played, gameplay is stilted - all the environments and levels are too large for how slowly you move, completely breaking the flow of the combat. Guns are vastly more effective than melee weapons, as I often died just getting into melee range. You expel the remainder of your clip when you reload, which leads me (as a compulsive reloader) to accidentally lose all my ammo. The writing is... 'poor' is an understatement. It's clearly a bad language port. No real story is given, literally every npc I met was absurdly rude to me, and it was generally just a really poor experience.

												A fun rpg shooter type game, can be complicated but once you get the hang of it there is a lot of depth in the way you can build your character. The overall theme of the game to me felt like some type of warhammer 40k, deus ex hybrid so if your are a fan of either of those games you may also enjoy the aesthetics. I enjoyed the game and for its price there is no reason not to try it.

												Terrible characters and translation issues climb atop a mountain of poorly explained gameplay to create E.Y.E., one of the most frustrating and enjoyable games I've played. There is a great deal of depth here, but the only help comes in the form of boring, mostly useless video "tutorials." However, even if you watch the videos and reference the community, you will still likely find yourself making mistakes to the point of needing to start the game over entirely. Research this game a great deal before purchase; I recommed an excellent review/analysis by a guy named Sexbad on youtube:

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												I came into this game knowing it wasn't going to be extremely great. It has a neat universe that is intriguing, and I like the cyberpunk kind of stuff.   First off, creating your character in the very beginning is a hassle, I had to look up what each "chemical" would do.Another thing, hacking is crazy difficult, and boring, yet it seems to be one of the main points of the game.Enemy AI must have X-ray/something-vision, as soon as I start one of the maing missions of the story (where you have a choice to be stealthy) the enemy is shooting and converging on me within walking two feet into the map. (mind you I have a sniper rifle and cannot hardly see the enemy from across the map with my scope 2x zoomed.)It's neat to explore around the game, and other than the very odd AI and leveling system ect, it's really fun to use the powers and watch the enemies tweak. And the gun play is good as well.Haven't done much multiplayer but it's seeming like this is going to be more of a multiplayer game for me.Overall it's a neat game, if it goes on sale get it, I bought it for one dollar so i'm not too bent out of shape, more dissapointed than anything.

												I don't realy recommend it or don't but im leaning towards recommending it a litttle more, the game has the aspects of borderlands , it VERY glitchy at times, bugs in the game that most likely aren't going to be addressed due to the fact that the devs have put their full attention in another game, so If you don't mind getting put on a map going and fullfilling missions moving back and forth OFTEN then be my guest, the game does offer a interesting skill/leveling system, and not so overpowered money making system as well, and multiplayer isn't so bad the community's well rounded but maps often fail due to bugs  ( example: your on a mission it requires you to kill all enemies and you guys have killed them all but the game doesn't wish to give you the mission complete because an enemy spawned in a wall or didn't register when killed or it just doesn't wanna move on to the next map)

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Well, E.Y.E is certainly something. It's a shooter with great upsides, and downsides, so only buy this if you feel the good outweighs the bad (i certainly do)Pros:-Interesting class system, your class is determined by the skills and augmentations you get, and not vice versa, and doesent really affect anything aside from giving you an aesthetic title - there is no actual limit to the combination of powers/augmentations you can get.-Good cyberpunk/surreal atmosphere - not many games have that kind of feel-Massive levels, with multiple paths for completion of each mission, so you can play it the way you want (you don't have to fire a single shot if you don't want to)-Fast paced gunplay, and action-packed awesomeness (you can jump onto a helicopter, shoot some guys below you, backstab the helicopter and jump off as it falls to its spiralling demise)-You play as a psychic cyber ninja monk paladin with amnesia who everybody seems to despise for no reasonCons-The story is completely and utterly insane, half the time i hve no idea what the hell i'm doing, or why i'm killing who i'm killing-Death is punished a little too harshly - i mean seriously, permanent stat debuffs? (well, I say permanent, there IS and endgame way to cure them, but as I said, it's endgame)-Enemies have ridiculous accuracy, though it is quite amusing to suddenly get sniped from accross the map by a bandit with an unscoped SMG-Playerbase is essentailly dead, so multiplayer (which is actually quite enjoyable) isnt really playable anymoreOverall Verdict:EYE is a game that seems to have been born out of the eldritch realm of Cthulhu during his reign of madness, but if you can see through all its unpolished edges and random shenanigans, you will find a unique game that you will not regret buying. (also, it costs only 10€, so why the hell not?)

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Not recommended for more casual gamers, certainly. I tried liking it, and though I saw some potential here, it was wasted by the game itself. Unusually stupid a.i., bad sound design, bad weapon balance, and overly complex menus are some of the more off-putting elements that made this game a novelty that wore off quickly. I didn't even bother attempting to delve more deeply into the story elements of the game, it seemed to be just a plagarized, inferior version of sci-fi tropes that I normally like.This game's greatest strength is the number of ways you can customize your character as you level.This game's greatest weakness is that you'll never be able to do anything else with your cool character than play in this boring, vapid, derivative world.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												This game is extremely weird... But also extremely cool. Genetically enhanced samurai-mafia and militia-gangsters and lots of science-magic! I have no idea what's going on in the game, but I think it's fun and makes somewhat sense. It's a bunch of skills you can upgrade, which in my opinion gives you alot of character-personality. I believe there is some kind of varied play-style, by for example summoning a bunch of cyborg-ninjas to fight for you, or you could run and gun. You can even just take the use of a mother♥♥♥♥ing hi-tech longsword that when you right-click, you summon a big♥♥♥♥♥vortex-shield that blocks of incoming bullets. And when you have blocked a few bullets,♥♥♥♥♥♥gets real and then you can play shadow-ninja and blink behind the enemys back and stick the blade up their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s! The only downside is that it lacks the biggest feature; weapon customization! The multiplayer contains jumping and a little bit of drugs... Fun! The games atmosphere is also quite cool-i-ool on the Source-engine.Ducks in sewers; 7/10.It's♥♥♥♥♥♥cheap, buy it! Buy a few copies to your friends and threaten them to cut of their ears if they don't try it!

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Very ambitious game with amazing visual design and a fairly interesting plot that requires multiple playthroughs and possibly a few visits to some discussion threads. There is a lot the developers tried to do here and much of it ends up falling short, but even when taking that in to consideration it manages to be a more interesting game than many of the titles you'll see on the front page these days. With more time and a larger budget I'm sure this would have turned out to be something really amazing. The price is always criminally low during sales so if you ever see it at 80-90% cop this♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, it's probably the best dollar or two you'll spend all year.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												A game experiance not unlike trying to juggle banie babies inside a tumble dryer full of bowling pins. with a story so convoluted and twisted, one is reccomended to bring along some heavy gin or asprin should you dare to try and understand it. clumsy video tutorials you need to shift through one by one make it difficult to get a clear understanding of the controls. areas and setpeices that seem devoid of life, not helped by the fact that all enemies spawn constantly and run at you in droves (usually in a straight line with no attempt to take cover) and an insanity system that seemed to effect me so badly I was unable to even read the instructions on how to rid myself of the madness induced blurry screen.Granted many of these things may be seen as positive things, and to be fair I did not play too far through, and for al it's faults this game is interesting if nothing else. give it a try on a sale but do not expect a warm welcome from E.Y.E.

												The good:-Ridiculously deep character building options-Cool visual aesthetic-Good soundtrack-The Bear Killer handgun is fun to useThe bad:-Mind-bogglingly horrible level layouts that will waste hours of your life-Braindead AI leads to meaningless combat-Some of the worst translation I've ever seen (this could be a plus if you find it funny)-Stupid storyline, made worse by aforementioned awful translation (same as above point)-Boring, repetitive hacking minigame-Requires grinding to get most of the upgrades in the gameOverall 3/10, clearly an amateur effort, would not recommend to anyone

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I've tried to come back and play this game several times since I first got it, but i can never make it more than 10-20 minutes before I get frustrated and quit. I can't recommend this game any more than I can properly review it as I haven't really played it. Everything I've read about this game and the trailers I've seen of it make it look really good, but from my personal experience, it's too confusing and clunky. All I've done in this game is create my character and make it to where the first enemies are. I've never seen them, but I can hear them shoot at me and their bullets end up killing me. aside from moving, jumping, and slashing with my sword, I'm not sure what there is to do in this game. I keep thinking I need to come back and give it a fair chance, but I can't bring myself to do it. I simply don't see the appeal. It mentions a multiplayer aspect and maybe that's why people play it. As for me, I only got it because it was on sale for $1. I don't plan to beat this game or do much more with it and I don't recommend it unless you think it's worth your time to try and  figure it out.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												This game isn't that complex really.  You pretty much have 4 or 5 options.  You can be a use psy powers to summon clones or teleport into battle, you can run around with a sword and deflect bullets, you can build yourself into a cyber warrior that can jump 500 feet in the air and throw cars, you can hack enemies and atm's taking direct control and you can be a gunslinger that headshots everyone. If you want, you can also lay down turrets and send around drones that will also help kill guys for you. You can be a mix of any of those things if you want. The game definitely has it's own lore and terminology and it really has so much going for it in a first person shooter it may be confusing. All of that being said, the game is open, your choices send you into new stages you may never have seen, and to truly beat the game you have to beat it 3 different times allying with 3 different forces and gaining 3 different superpowered psy powers.  One thing that I wasn't expecting with this game is that for the vast majority of it enemies spawn endlessly, you can customize the frequency of it but keep that in mind as it does make a difference. It's also important to note the game is incredibly insane.  Seriously, it's very crazy.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2011
												Great atmosphere, challenging missions and good gameplay (thanks to the source engine), but at the end of the day it feels like a mod because so many things have been directly transported from the Half-Life series. Sometimes I think the developers suffered from delusions of grandeur when designing this game and have obviously missed a lot stuff. The game is also ridden with bugs at the moment but there is some hope on that matter, as the developers are listening to the community and acknowleding the bugs - but it needs much more than one patch to be actually good. Right now, it will be good for a small percentage of hardcore sci-fi/atmospheric shooter fans like myself. Fans of games like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. might find it good as well, because the punishment you'll take here is just as high...

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												Typically, bad games make the player realize how bad it is about halfway through. E.Y.E. is a bad game, but at least you realize how bad it is right from the begining. I guess that is actually a pretty polite thing on the developers part. So at least there's that.The game starts you off in a character creation screen with no idea what you're doing. You see a bunch of stats and 3 gene code things which modify the stats in different ways. It's really complicated and totally overwhelming. You have no idea what kind of character you're creating or what he will be good at. A good RPG needs to have a helpful and clear character creation screen so players know what kind of character they are creating. You don't want to absolutely overhwelm them so they don't know what to pick. The exception, of course, is games based on rulesets that already exist like D&D or Shadowrun, which for EYE is not the case. When you finish with that you get thrown into the actual game without any kind of backdrop. You have no idea why you're there, what you're doing, or even who you are. An npc starts talking to you pretty quick but it must be some foreign language or made-up language because I didn't understand it. (An extremely bizzare stylistic choice). Thankfully, there are subtitles but its distracting to read them while you're playing! When you finally have an actual conversation nobody tells you what is going on. The writing is really, really sloppy too. The NPC's don't act like real people, more like robots in a museum (they just spit lines of dialouge at you without any emotion.)If you play RPG's you know what I mean when I say that the game needs to immediately draw the player into the game right off the bat. You want them to know what is going on and get them interested so that they will want to continue playing. You don't want to confuse them and make them feel lost. These are the barest basics, and yet EYE fails at it. The gameplay mechanics, such as hacking and leveling your character are also pretty confusing. You get tutorial videos that try to help you out, but they move too fast and aren't voice acted. There are subtitles but they moved too fast for me to read. As far as I'm concerned, the tutorial videos are useless. EYE has the lowest budget and worst design I have ever seen. It's like the developers were ADD high school kids who made it in a week on 100 bucks.
