content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This is a horrible Deus Ex clone coded in the Source/Halflife 2 engine. Missions are a bit weird (and some maps are TEDIOUSLY large), hacking mechanics are stupid, combat is dumb, stealth is impossible, and you will die before you figure out what is killing you far too often. Also the story-telling ends up coming off as convoluted instead of mysterious. While EYE would probably be a little more enjoyable in multiplayer, i don't see why anyone would ever encourage their friends to get this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Prepended edit: The wasted potential I'm seeing the more I think about this game is getting to me. This is one of the most love/hate reviews I've ever written. I'm going to try one more time to salvage this. I'm going to find a translation mod. I'm going to screw with the reinforcement settings and try to turn off the nonsense without making the game trivial. I'll try one more time and update the review accordingly if anything comes of it. But I'm not getting my hopes up.Phase 1: Already seeing issues with the  text revamp mod. I like how clean the dialog and UI text is made in places it needs it but it kind of changes the characters and lore in a way I don't think the developers would appreciate. This is why I said it wasn't enough.Phase 2: Even turning down the reinforcements to minimal and checking the "limit reinforcements" box results in getting mobbed and having enemies spawn behind you (this is something source is know for, but usually authors utilize such spawning in a better way). I've seen this compared to Diablo or other ARPGs but that's not true. Usually in these sorts of games the mobs don't spawn behind you and are limited per floor. Not the case here.Phase 3 (final): One more thing to add. The branches of the dialog trees tend to merge quickly. Meaning that oftentimes something you choose to say will get an equivalent response to the other option. This is fine and lets you have some roleplaying but the problem is understanding when those branches are going to merge and in the cases where they do lead to different responses understanding if those branches are hostile and lead to you getting shot several hundred times. This is not an easy task given the localization. Besides that, the hacking minigame (mentioned below) has a lot of potential (like the rest of the damn game) but the implementation needs work. The AI's algorithm relies heavily on a loop of overflow (increase your attack at the cost of defense) -> Attack -> Shield (raise defense). This is quite exploitable since they bring down their own defense so much. You can get it stuck somewhat in a loop by continually masking (reducing enemy attack), overflowing and then attacking. It seems to put a lot of priority in its attack points which lead to its downfall.So yeah, consider all of the above when you read the main review and remember that I gave it a hell of a chance and tried to love it as my time proves. But like Frozen Synapse it rejects me utterly.----I've never played a game that claimed to be cyberpunk and felt so disappointed. This is Serious Sam without the competence of croteam. Seriously, the RPG parts are impossible to understand because of bad localization (which makes speaking to NPCs and other lore pointless) and in the end the character leveling and such doesn't even matter because the enemies spawn endlessly and have no real identity. There is an option related to enemy reinforcements but that doesn't change that the combat is very badly done.I tried hard to like this because on its face the lore looked interesting and I enjoy it when games don't stick their head up their♥♥♥♥♥trying to do full voice acting (text allows much greater detail, like it or not). I tried hard enough that I played for 5 hours and dealt with aforementioned combat, broken Russian english and mildly annoying UI. Through those 5 hours I still feel as if though I'm not understanding much. Be it gameplay or plot related. Despite carefully trying to read all the archive logs, NPC dialog and every tutorial video I feel as if though I missed a ton of stuff.I'd rather play Fallout honestly, and I would be if I wasn't so afraid of the massive timesink it tends to turn into.Also, I couldn't help but notice that this borrows quite a few concepts from other stuff. Which is fine but honestly the plot isn't anything special. Nor is the backstory. From what I (barely) understand the early years of the game world was something akin to Warhammer 40K. Right down to them mentioning psykers by name and how the army would hunt them one way or the other and the ones that don't join willingly are killed sooner than the ones who do.I will say this much though. I loved the hacking system. It's just about the closest thing yet to what I've always wanted one to be. It's like a combat in itself with status text and attacks and everything. It's not just a dead simple "you hack this, connect these stupidly easy dots, you get monies" sort of deal. That's part of the reason I wish so desperately that this was better in every other regard. There's some technically interesting stuff hiding behind all of this somewhere.Edit: After thinking on it for a while. I can only summarize it thusly: The most truly depressing thing about it is that if they had did a decent localization. I could deal with all of this and like it even. No. Fan made loc patches aren't good enough for this much stuff. You need the authors' original intent carried over directly as best as possible. As is it you basically just randomly fight through the masses to get to whatever waypoint and figure out what to do by whatever vague hints you get. Then do stuff, then repeat without ever actually knowing what you're doing.Super duper final edit: 14 hours. I've tried for 14 hours to convince this game to let me love it. It's not working. I've uninstalled it and reinstalled it 4 times now. Now I'm not joking. I seriously did. Every time I attempt to play again I just see the insta-spawn enemies mobbing towards me and the incomprehensible dialog I think "Hrm, I could be playing New Vegas right now".  Even the hacking lost its novelty once I discovered the rather simple pattern of the AI. Probably going to do the final uninstall now.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												It took me a long time to get into this game, but the end result is still disappointment. I really like the Blade Runner meets Deus Ex (original) vibe this game was going for. I think it pulled that part off spectacularly well. The gunplay is also visceral and satisfying. So why don't I recommend this game?For starters, the brouzouf system is pretty awful. It's like the souls from Demon's/Dark souls - it does everything! Too much, as a matter of fact, for me to care considering how expensive all of the research, personal upgrades, weapon unlocks, etc. are. The starting weapons are a little too good, IMO. Because after grabbing a farming map and unlocking a few of the weapons, things like the TRK (?) sniper rifle are still just completely dominant in terms of accuracy and damage output.Another item is the checkpoint/saving system. One moment, it's saving after certain missions; the next, it's not saving throughout the course of a level I invested about 2 hours in. IT'S RIDICULOUS THAT THIS IS SO INCONSISTENT. Just put in a damn quick save button/manual save option.Side problems, I cranked the brightness way up because during underground levels, I couldn't even see enemies without the EYE vision (more often than not, way too zoomed in to be useful with any scoped weapon).If you are major into grinding and farming games, I guess you'll like EYE. If you want a game with a tight feeling to all of its elements, this definitely isn't for you. It requires a lot of personal motivation to figure out what is going on and enjoy.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												While I think this is a solid game with a very interesting and bizzare world to explore and learn about, there's one thing that I dislike so much that I'm giving this game a thumbs down, and it's the "fatal wounds" system.This system causes you to have a chance to permanently loose stat points upon death or when using high-level abilities without enough energy.  I dislike this because this implies that even if you reach the max level, you can still lose stat points that may be irrecoverable.I dislike the idea that you can't recover these stat points.  There may be a way to recover the points that I'm unaware of but that doesn't stop this concept from being frustrating.  I don't want to loose something as important as stat points permanently.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2011
												It's like a FPS Diablo like but a lot more fun and a lot more original than Hellgate : London which was the first FPS using that approach.There's a strong coherent mood build from graphics, Cyberpunk thematic, story and lore background. It makes the game quite bizarre and fascinating. The writing alternate both very good parts mainly from lore and too many dialogs with a very exaggerate vulgarity. If you can go over the vulgarity problem the writing complete very well the mood and setup a quite fascinating and bizarre game.The action too is very fun and offers many different approaches depending of the RPG elements you choose to develop for your character. For example you can focus on hacking with many stuff to hack including some enemies or even yourself to remove a hack on your character, or you can use stealth a lot or not, or use more sniping, and so on.The shooting is rather great and sometimes quite challenging, the levels are large but also quite non linear. There's also good puzzles and tricks to find that are well merged to the action and to the story evolution. It's not a perfectly polished game but that's a unique great FPS with RPG elements.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												Well ladies and gentlemen, I must admit that I am stumped. I'm not sure how to review indie dev Streum On Studio's latest title, E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy. so instead I will describe the experience I have had while playing it.E.Y.E starts out by asking you to chose gene sequences to define your character's traits. After you have decided on your character's attributes you start out in some sort of dream sequence/trance. After exiting the door in said dream/trance, you are immediately thrust into a combat situation against rival factions, and this is where I admittedly lost track of the plot. That's quite alright though, because at that point I got to experience the wonderful combat system.Combat and inventory management in E.Y.E is a little bit Deus EX, a little bit System Shock. You are limited by what weapons/ammo/items you can fit into your inventory grid. I was able to carry a minigun, dual handguns, and a lovely katana into battle, along with plenty of ammo. The minigun just chews through your foes like nothing else, and at 500 rounds per clip, reloads are few and far between. Successfully dispatching enemies earn you "Brouzof" points, I'm still not sure what they do however.Once you get past the initial missions in the game, and start to get your bearings, that is when you start to realize the vast scope of the developer's vision. It may not make a whole lot of sense, however you can still appreciate the intense Matrix on LSD vibe they have going. E.Y.E is a surreal experience that is not for everyone, but if you have a taste for a deep world with plenty of secrets to unravel, this may just be the game you have been looking for.Hacking is an interesting feature in E.Y.E, it works out like a realtime battle whener you have to apply hacks and counterhacks, and stay one step forward of what it is that you are trying to gain access to, because every hackable item in the game, be it a door or a computer, can hack you back. In the case this happens, you are infected with a virus that you have to deal with before you can continue.I have thoroughly enjoyed the time I have spent in the trippy world of E.Y.E, and my only real complaint is that you cannot save anytime/anywhere, instead the game saves your progress at predetermined checkpoints, and also when you enter a main hub. One of the devs assured me that this is so you have to consider your actions carefully, instead of just rushing in guns blazing.

												The Dualist Pan-Techno Knowledge of the Puppet Master my♥♥♥♥♥ This is basically a collection of multiplayer maps with NPC enemies in them and some really badly scripted missions. Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game, is honestly terrible. Most of the mechanics presented in game ("Hacking", etc) are INCREDIBLY half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥to the point they're pretty useless. In regards to combat, it's pretty "meh" and enemies, once they detect you -Which isn't difficult in the slightest- suddenly become omniscient beings who know where you are forever, with perfect accuracy.The inventory system is a major pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to deal with. You have a limited number of slots to put items in, and each item added reduces your overall speed.Also, thanks to the downright AWFUL translation job (The original FF7 had a better translations!) the story is a nonsensicle MESS.Overall, avoid this game like the plague.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2011
												Don't buy it...unless you are curious and see it on sale for $0.90 or something less!!! I recommend you save your money...I paid full price so it's partly why I'm p'ssd.  I didn't bother to check when this game was made and I should have, but it feels like pre-2000.  There is no voice acting all the interaction is all text like pre-2000 so there is a huge amount of reading, something you don't expect for an rpg/shooter type. The environments etc are weird and not entirely clear to where you have to go.  Probably because there is so much crap to read during interactions I can't be bothered to read and so not clear on stuff.  The hacking is muddy to say the least... It's crap in short... Stupid game because there's far too much you have to figure out on your own because of the poor design... avoid it... there are wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy better games out there!  Unless it's on sale for super cheap and you want to satisfy your curiousity ... or it's getting handed out for free somewhere!

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Bee Movie is a 2007 American computer animated family comedy film produced by DreamWorks Animation and distributed by Paramount Pictures. It stars Jerry Seinfeld and Renée Zellweger.Bee Movie is the first motion-picture script to be written by Seinfeld, who co-wrote the film with Spike Feresten, Barry Marder, and Andy Robin. The film was directed by Simon J. Smith and Steve Hickner and produced by Seinfeld, Christina Steinberg and Cameron Stevning. The production was designed by Alex McDowell, and Christophe Lautrette was the art director. Nick Fletcher was the supervising editor and music for the film was composed by Rupert Gregson-Williams.The cast and crew include some veterans of Seinfeld's long-running NBC sitcom Seinfeld, including writer/producers Feresten and Robin, and actors Michael Richards (Seinfeld character Cosmo Kramer), Patrick Warburton (Seinfeld character David Puddy), and Larry Miller (who plays the title character on the Seinfeld episode "The Doorman"). Coincidentally, NBC was host to the broadcast television premiere of the film on November 27, 2010.

												This game, in a single word, is baffling. I cannot see any reason why a semi-intelligent human being would invest more than an iota of time into what is, quite franky, the worst excuse for a game I have ever played. The gameplay is awful and unintuitive, the character development (and development is a generous word) is disappointing to say the least, and, perhaps most tragically, the graphics (renders) are dogshit. The tutorials couldn't explain to a grown man how to open a tin of beans. This game sucks♥♥♥♥♥ and I give it a well-deserved 2/10.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												If you like video games that have terrible tutorial systems, bad audio, and not telling you a thing at all about making your character than this is the game for you.  It totally wont hold your hand but it wont teach you anything at all.  The game will even tell you to look up abilities in the tutorial that are not actually listed in it.  I hope you like intros that are just walking through a dank cave with no context and audio that can make you physically ill because that is what you are getting.  This game is absolutely NOT new player friendly and if you expect a game to actually be understandable, you should not play this.
